{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Akil N Awan''' is a British [[academia|academic]] and the current RCUK Fellow in the 'Contemporary History of Faith, Power and Terror' and Lecturer in both International Terrorism and Contemporary Islam in the Department of History and the Department of Politics and International Relations, at [[Royal Holloway, University of London]] (RHUL). He is also a current Research Associate both with the Centre for Ethnic Minority Studies (CEMS), and with the New Political Communication Unit (NPCU) at Royal Holloway. Previously he has served as a Research Associate on the ESRC project Shifting Securities: News Cultures Before and Beyond the Iraq War.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mediatingsecurity.com/links.htm |title=Mediated Security – Shifting Securities – Links |publisher=Mediatingsecurity.com |date= |accessdate=4 March 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529185229/http://www.mediatingsecurity.com/links.htm |archive-date=29 May 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Research interests & expertise == His key research interests at present are focused around: * The history and evolution of [[al-Qaeda]] * The rise of Global Jihadism * The International Mujahideen movement during the [[Afghan-Soviet War]] (1979–89), the [[Bosnian War]] (1992–95), the [[First Chechen War]] (1994–96), the [[War of Dagestan]] (1999), the [[Second Chechen War]] (1999–2009) and the [[Insurgency in the North Caucasus]] (2009–) * Root causes and antecedents of Islamic Political Radicalism and Terrorism (i.e. what is increasingly referred to as [[Radicalisation]]) * The use of virtual media and the Internet by Jihadist groups; * Changing configurations of religious authority sources/structures and its effects on increasing political radicalisation and ideological support for terrorism; * Changes in religiosity and issues of identity formulation particularly vis-à-vis religion. * He also teaches graduate courses on the [[History of Terrorism]]<ref>http://www.rhul.ac.uk/History/undergrad/undergrad_coursecatalogue.html#3350</ref> and New Political Communication.
Aside from being awarded the prestigious Research Councils UK Fellowship in 2006, he is also the current co-holder of a major [[ESRC]] & FCO research grant on 'Legitimising the discourses of radicalisation: Political violence in the new media ecology’<ref>http://www.esrcsocietytoday.ac.uk/ESRCInfoCentre/ViewAwardPage.aspx?ts=3&data=v9XrjLJ6xhHUnxcP5mrhZF3Fle8udGx%2B6W1K4nYpfXYufPhwUL6v0g%3D%3D</ref> under the New Security Challenges: Radicalisation & Violence programme.
He is a member of the War and Media Academic Network, the European Consortium for Political research (ECPR) Standing Group on Internet & Politics, and of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20090830010503/http://www.mbrn.org.uk/index.html Muslims in Britain Academic Research Network (MBRN)]
Akil Awan is regularly consulted by government bodies, other organisations, and the media in his fields of expertise, and has served in an advisory capacity and on numerous Working Groups for The Home Office, RICU, The Foreign & Commonwealth Office (FCO), the Office for Security & Counter Terrorism (OSCT), Joint Terrorism Analysis Centre (JTAC), Wilton Park,<ref>Wilton Park (2007) The Struggle for Unity and Authority in Islam: Reviving the Caliphate, Wilton Park & Center for Strategic Studies. MISC D0016777.A2 http://www.wiltonpark.org.uk/documents/conferences/WP886/pdfs/WP886prog.pdf</ref> the International Centre for the Study of Radicalisation (ICSR),<ref>ICSR (2009) Countering Online Radicalisation: A Strategy for Action, ICSR: London. http://www.icsr.info/news/attachments/1236768445ICSROnlineRadicalisationReport.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721205503/http://www.icsr.info/news/attachments/1236768445ICSROnlineRadicalisationReport.pdf |date=21 July 2011 }}</ref> International Institute of Strategic Studies (IISS) & the Insurgency Research Group (IRG). He is also a regular commentator to the Media and his research has appeared in Dispatches (Ch4), The Birmingham Post,<ref>The Birmingham Post (2006) Muslims 'do not have to wear it', 16 October 2006 http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-152849077.html</ref> The Western Mail,<ref>Karl Mansfield (2006) Expert says there is no theological justification for the wearing of the Veil (Niqab), The Western Mail, 16 October 2006 http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-152876485.html</ref> The Economist,<ref>The Economist (2006) Chasing Shadows: On-campus extremism in Britain, The Economist, 19 October 2006 http://www.economist.com/world/britain/displaystory.cfm?story_id=8057937</ref> the LA Times, Reuters,<ref>Michael Holden (2007) Experts say West can't stop Web radicalization, Reuters, 6 November 2007 https://www.reuters.com/article/technologyNews/idUSL2658640020071106</ref> FOCUS (Ger), The Boston Globe (US), China Post,<ref>The China Post (2007) West struggles in vain against radicalization on the Internet, 8 November 2007 http://www.chinapost.com.tw/international/2007/11/08/130040/West-struggles.htm</ref> MSNBC (US), Sydney Morning Herald (Aus),<ref>Sydney Morning Herald (2007) The internet is the new Afghanistan, Sydney Morning Herald, 7 November 2007 http://www.smh.com.au/news/web/the-internet-is-the-new-afghanistan/2007/11/07/1194329277184.html</ref> BBC World Service, and Dawn (Pak).
== Recent Publications ==
* Awan, A. N. (2009) 'Success of the Meta-Narrative: How Jihadists Maintain Legitimacy', in [[CTC Sentinel]], vol. 2(11): 6–9.<ref>http://www.ctc.usma.edu/sentinel/CTCSentinel-Vol2Iss11.pdf</ref> * Awan, A. N. & Al-Lami, M. (2009) ‘Al-Qaeda’s Virtual Crisis’, in Journal of the [[Royal United Services Institute]], vol. 154(1): 56–64.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a909918203~db=all~jumptype=rss |title=Al-Qa'ida's Virtual Crisis – The RUSI Journal |publisher=Informaworld.com |date=1 February 2009 |accessdate=4 March 2010}}</ref> * Awan, A. N. (2009) 'The Emperor's new words', in Britain in 2008 (ESRC). * Awan, A. N. (2008) 'Antecedents of Islamic Political Radicalism Among Muslim Communities in Europe', in Political Science & Politics, vol. 41(1): 13–17.(Jan)<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=1631032&fulltextType=RA&fileId=S1049096508080013 |title=CJO – Abstract – Antecedents of Islamic Political Radicalism Among Muslim Communities in Europe |publisher=Journals.cambridge.org |date=11 January 2008 |accessdate=4 March 2010}}</ref> * Awan, A. N. (2007a) 'Transitional Religiosity Experiences: Contextual Disjuncture and Islamic Political Radicalism', in T. Abbas (ed.) Islamic Political Radicalism: A European comparative perspective, Edinburgh University Press: Edinburgh, pp. 207–30.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PD2LPGyMHOkC&pg=PA207&lpg=PA207&dq=akil+awan#v=onepage&q=akil%20awan&f=false |title=Islamic political radicalism: a ... – Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=7 July 2005 |accessdate=4 March 2010|isbn=978-0-7486-2528-4}}</ref> * Awan, A. N. (2007b) 'Virtual Jihadist media: Function, legitimacy, and radicalising efficacy', in European Journal of Cultural Studies (Special Issue), vol. 10(3), pp. 389–408.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://ecs.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/10/3/389|last1=Awan|first1=A. N. |title=Virtual jihadist media: Function, legitimacy and radicalizing efficacy – Awan 10 (3): 389 – European Journal of Cultural Studies |doi=10.1177/1367549407079713 |publisher=Ecs.sagepub.com|pages=389|volume=10 |date= |journal=European Journal of Cultural Studies|accessdate=4 March 2010 |issue=3}}</ref> * Awan, A. N. (2007c) 'Radicalization on the Internet? The Virtual Propagation of Jihadist Media and its Effects', in Journal of the Royal United Services Institute, vol. 152(3).<ref>http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a779648314?words=awan</ref> * Awan, A. N. (2009) ‘Virtual Jihadist media’, in Manual of Islamic Movements (Ed. F. Peter), Casa Arabe: Madrid (to be published in English, Spanish and Arabic).
He is currently working on three books on: * 'The Rise of al-Qaeda and the Global Jihad' for Routledge * 'Processes of Radicalisation' for EUP * 'Radicalisation & the Media' for Routledge (Co-authored with Hoskins & O’Loughlin)<ref>http://www.routledgestrategicstudies.com/books/Radicalisation-and-the-Media-ISBN 978-0-415-55035-2</ref> * and is also editing a volume on ‘Islamisms on the Internet’.
He is also working on a documentary on 'The History of al-Qaeda', to be released in 2011.{{update after|2011|12|31}}{{update after|2011|12|31}}

{{Infobox building | name = Chernihiv Ancient | native_name = Чернігів стародавній | native_name_lang = <!-- images --> | logo = | logo_size = | logo_caption = | image = Spasopreobrazh-cathedral-chernihiv.JPG | image_size = | image_caption = Saviour-Transfiguration Cathedral of 11th century <!-- map --> | map_type = | pushpin_relief = | image_map = | map_caption = <!-- location --> | location = Chernihiv Oblast | address = | location_city = Chernihiv | location_country = Ukraine | coordinates = {{coord|51|29|28|N|31|17|55|E|display=inline,title}} <!-- stats --> | former_names = | alternate_names = | etymology = | status = | cancelled = | topped_out = | building_type = National Architecture-Historical Sanctuary | architectural_style = | material = | classification = | altitude = | namesake = | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | stop_date = | est_completion = | completion_date = | opened_date = State Sanctuary | inauguration_date = | closing_date = | demolition_date = | destruction_date = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = | affiliation = | height = | architectural = | structural_system = | size = | floor_count = | floor_area = | elevator_count = | grounds_area = | architect = | architecture_firm = | developer = | engineer = | known_for = | website = [http://oldchernihiv.com/ oldchernihiv.com] | embed = | embedded = | references = | footnotes = }} '''Chernihiv Ancient''' ({{lang-uk|Чернігів стародавній|translit=Chernihiv starodavniy}}) is the National Architecture-Historical Sanctuary located in the north-eastern [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] city of [[Chernihiv]]. It was created at first as an affiliate of the [[National Sanctuary "Sophia of Kiev"]]. Since August 1, 1967 the site is a separate entity consisting of 34 monuments of architecture.
==Architectural landmarks== * [[Detinets|Detynets]] of Chernihiv, also known as Chernihiv's [[Motte-and-bailey|motte]] ([[Earthwork (archaeology)|earthwork]]) * [[Transfiguration Cathedral, Chernihiv|Saviour-Transfiguration Cathedral]] * Chernihiv's Collegium (see [[Collegium (disambiguation)|collegium]]) * House of Lyzohub (Colonel of the Chernihiv's Regiment) * House of Archbishop * Governor's House * Beautiful Square * Church of Preparatory Friday * Cathrine Church * Yelets-Dormition Monastery * Trinity-Ilna Monastery with Antonie Caves * [[Black Grave]] ([[kurgan]])
Since 1989, the site is placed on the tentative list of the [[United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization|United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO)]] as part of "World Heritage", receiving its reference as number 668.<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/668/ Historic Centre of Tchernigov, 9th -13th centuries]</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Чернигов. Елецкий монастырь.jpg|Yelets-Dormition monastery's cathedral was modeled after that of [[Kiev Pechersk Lavra]]. File:Чернігів.Собор Бориса й Гліба.JPG|Borys-Hlib Cathedral in front of Saviour-Transfiguration Cathedral. File:AX Chernihiv Pyatnytska Church.jpg|The Church of [[Paraskevi of Iconium|Preparatory]] Friday (c. 1201, restored after World War II). </gallery>
==See also== * [[List of historic reserves in Ukraine]] * [[List of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Ukraine]]

'''Antranig Chalabian''' (March 11, 1922, [[Kessab]], [[Syria]] – April 12, 2011, [[Southfield, Michigan|Southfield]], [[Michigan]]) was a medical illustrator, cartographer and historian, an author of several volumes on [[Armenian history]]. He is best known for his biography of General [[Andranik Ozanyan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/world/news/67959/ |title=Armenian history volumes author Antranig Chalabian dies at 89. Panarmenian.Net, 2011 |publisher=Panarmenian.net |date=2011-04-22 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hpj.asj-oa.am/5281/ |title=Անդրանիկ Չելեպյան. Զորավար Անդրանիկ և հայ հեղափոխական շարժումը , Երևան, 1990 թ., 720 էջ։ - Պատմա-բանասիրական հանդես =Historical-Philological Journal |publisher=Hpj.asj-oa.am |date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
==Biography== He was born in 1922 in Kessab.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirrorspectator.com/2011/04/21/dr-antranig-chalabian-author-of-historical-volumes-dies/ |title=Dr. Antranig Chalabian, Author Of Historical Volumes, Dies |publisher=Mirrorspectator.com |date=2011-04-21 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref> After graduating from the Armenian Evangelical School, he studied at Aleppo College. Then, in the summer of 1949, Chalabian moved to Beirut and took a position in the physiology department of the [[American University of Beirut]] (AUB). In 1977, Chalabian and his family immigrated to the [[Detroit, USA]], where Chalabian worked as public relations director at the AGBU Alex Manoogian School.<ref>[http://www.abrilbooks.com/artists/789.html Antranig Chalabian] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120034020/http://www.abrilbooks.com/artists/789.html |date=November 20, 2008 }}</ref>
In 1984 he published his first historical book ''General Andranik and the Armenian Revolutionary Movement''. In 1989 at the History Department of the [[Yerevan State University]] he was awarded a doctorate in history. The book was later translated into English, Turkish, Greek and Spanish. The book became an instant best seller (75,000 copies sold only in Armenia). Academician Mkrtich G. Nersisyan called the book a "valuable historical work resulted by many years of persistent research".<ref>M. Nersisyan, ''Patmutyan Keghdzararnere'' (articles), Yerevan, "Gitutyun", 1998, p. 216</ref> Chalabian is also the author of ''Revolutionary Figures'' (1991),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://groong.usc.edu/tcc/tcc-20040202.html |title=Revolutionary Figures |publisher=Groong.usc.edu |date=2004-02-02 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref> ''Armenia After Coming of Islam'' and ''Dro'' books.
Chalabian received numerous accolades and recognition. The mayor of Southfield designated in 2005 a day as Dr. Antranig Chalabian Day in recognition of his goodwill ambassadorship of the city through his readers worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keghart.com/Apelian_Chalabian |title=Antranig, The First Born, Is No More, by Dr. Vahe H. Apelian, 14 April 2011 |publisher=Keghart.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref> He was an invited contributor to ''Military History'' Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirrorspectator.com/2011/04/21/dr-antranig-chalabian-author-of-historical-volumes-dies/ |title=Dr. Antranig Chalabian, Author Of Historical Volumes, Dies // "The Armenian Mirror-Spectator", Apr 21, 2011 |publisher=Mirrorspectator.com |date=2011-04-21 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref> and regularly contributed articles to the Armenian publications like ''[[Spurk]]'', ''[[Nayiri (periodical)|Nayiri]]'', ''Chanasser'', ''[[Armenian Mirror-Spectator]]'' and ''[[Andranikological Review]]'' papers.
Before writing and publishing his books, Dr. Antranig Chalabian collaborated with Dr. [[Stanley Kerr]] after discovering Dr. Kerr’s personal notes in the attic of the Physiology Department. Dr. Stanley Kerr had moved to New Jersey after retiring in 1965 from his distinguished career as the Chairman of the Biochemistry Department of the American University of Beirut. However, he had left his notes behind assuming that the notes were long lost through the years. Stanley Kerr had kept his notes and taken hitherto unpublished pictures while serving in [[Near East Relief]]. In 1919 Stanley was transferred to Marash, in central Anatolia, where he headed the American relief operations. The outcome of their collaborative work was the publication of Dr. Stanley Kerr’s ''[[The Lions of Marash]]'' in 1973.
While collaborating with Dr. Kerr, [[Henry Wilfrid Glockler]], a one-time controller at AUB and a neighbor of the Kerrs in Princenton, entrusted Antranig Chalabian his personal memoirs. Chalabian edited the memoirs and had it published in Beirut in 1969 by ''Sevan'' publishing house. The book is titled ''Interned in Turkey''.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Thomism}} '''Bartholomew of Lucca''', born '''Bartolomeo Fiadóni''', and also known as '''Tolomeo da Lucca''' or '''Ptolemy da Lucca'''<ref>Ptolemy or Tolomeo da Lucca, Tolomeo di Lucca, Bartolomeus de Fiadonibus.</ref> (c. 1236 – c. 1327), was a [[Middle Ages|medieval]] [[Italy|Italian]] historian.
==Biography== Born in [[Lucca]], probably in 1236, at an early age Bartholomew entered the [[Dominican Order]]. He was distinguished for piety, and his intense application to study, for which reasons he won the respect and warm friendship of [[St. Thomas Aquinas]]. He was not only his disciple, but also his confidant and [[confessor]].<ref>''Ptolom., H. E., XXIII, viii''.</ref> In 1272 he accompanied St. Thomas from [[Rome]] to [[Naples]] where he still was in 1274, when the news of his master's death at [[Fossa Nuova]] reached him. He was elected prior of the convent of his native city in 1288. At Naples (1294), he took an active part in the public demonstration which was made to prevent [[Pope Celestine V]] from resigning.
In 1301 he was elected Prior of [[Santa Maria Novella]] at [[Florence]]. Later he removed to [[Avignon]] where he was chaplain for nine years (1309–18) to [[Cardinal Patrasso]], [[Bishop of Albano]], and after the Cardinal's death in 1311 to his fellow-religious [[Cardinal William of Bayonne]]. [[Jacques Échard]] affirms that he was the close friend and often the confessor of [[John XXII]], who appointed him Bishop of [[Torcello]], March 15, 1318. A conflict with the [[Patriarch of Grado]] concerning the appointment of an abbess of St. Anthony's at Torcello led to his [[excommunication]] in 1321, and exile. In 1323 he made peace with the patriarch, returned to his see, and died there in 1327.<ref>On the life of Bartholomew, see Ludwig Schmugge, "[http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/bartolomeo-fiadoni_(Dizionario-Biografico)/ FIADONI, Bartolomeo] (Tolomeo, Ptolomeo da Lucca)", in ''Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani'', 47 (1997).</ref>
==Works== The best-known work of Bartholomew is his ''Annales'' (1061–1303), finished about 1307, wherein are recorded in terse sentences the chief events of this period.<ref>Muratori, ''Rerum Italicarum Scriptores,'' XI, 1249 sqq.; or in the better edition of C. Minutoli, ''Documenti di Storia Italiana,'' Florence, 1876, VI, 35 sqq..</ref> His ''Historia Ecclesiastica Nova'' in twenty-four books relates the history of the Church from the birth of [[Christ]] till 1294; considering as appendixes the lives of [[Pope Boniface VIII]], [[Pope Benedict XI]], and [[Pope Clement V]], it reaches to 1314 (Muratori, loc. cit., XI, 751 sqq.; the life of Clement V is in Baluze, ''Vitae pap. Aven.,'' 23 sqq.).
He also wrote a ''Historia Tripartita'' known only from his own references and citations. The ''Extract[us] de chronico Fr. Ptolomaei de Luca'' and the ''Excerpta ex chronicis Fr. Ptolomaei'' are no longer considered original works by separate authors, but are extracts from the ''Historia Ecclesiastica Nova'' by some unknown compiler who lived after the death of Bartholomew. He is also well known for his completion of the ''De Regimine Principum'' ("On the Government of Rulers"), which Aquinas had been unable to finish before his death. This was no small task, for the share of Bartholomew begins with the sixth chapter of the second book and includes the third and fourth books (vol. XVI, in the Parma, 1865, edition of St. Thomas). Though he does not follow the order of the saint, yet his treatment is clear and logical.
A work on the ''[[Hexameron|Hexaemeron]]'' by him was published by Masetti in 1880. The lives of the [[Avignon Papacy|Avignon popes]] were written from original documents under his hands and were controlled by the statements of eyewitnesses. His acceptance of [[fables]] now exploded, e.g. the [[Pope Joan|Popess Joan]], must be attributed to the uncritical temper of his time.
==Editions== * Ptolemy of Lucca. ''On the Government of Rulers (De Regimine Principum).'' Tr. James M. Blythe. Philadelphia, 1997.
==Notes== <references/>
;Attribution *{{Catholic|wstitle=Bartholomew of Lucca|volume=2}}

{{Infobox writer | name = Bernard Desclot | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = BernatDesclot.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = The Bernard Desclot monument which was built in 1888 and was destroyed in 1937. The photograph was taken in 1910 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1288 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = | language = [[Catalan language]] | nationality = [[Catalans|Catalan]] | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = [[Chroniclers|Chronicler]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Bernard Desclot''' (in [[Catalan language|Catalan]]: Bernat Desclot) was a [[Catalonia|Catalan]] [[chronicle]]r whose work covering the brief reign of [[Peter III of Aragon]] (1276–85) forms one of the four ''Catalan Grand Chronicles'' through which the modern historian views thirteenth- and fourteenth century military and political matters in the [[Kingdom of Aragon]] and the [[Principality of Catalonia]],<ref>The other three sources are the autobiographies of [[James I of Aragon]] and [[Ramon Muntaner]] and the royal chronicle of [[Peter IV of Aragon]].</ref> including the "[[Aragonese Crusade]]". Desclot's ''Chronicle'' begins in the eleventh century but gains especial interest when he comes to describe events current within living memory. Bernard's literary model was [[Romance (heroic literature)|Romance]], and his account is spiced with dramatic monologues of the central characters and thrilling episodes, such as the escape of Peter's brother, [[James II of Majorca]], from the fortress of [[Perpignan]], through the castle's drains.
Nothing of Bernard himself is known save what little can be gleaned through his ''Chronicle''.
F.L. Critchlow provided an English translation of the section covering the reign of Peter III in ''Chronicle of the Reign of King Peter III of Aragon, 1276-85'' (Princeton University Press) 1928.
== Galery == <gallery> Crònica-bernat-desclot-ms-1-BC-f8r.jpg Crònica-desclot-ms-647-BNE.f33r.aragonesos-i-catalans copy.jpg Desclot2.jpg Ms.486 Bib.de Cataluña. Barcelona-2.jpg|Page of Bernard's chronicle (Ms.486 Bib.de Catalunya, Barcelona) </gallery>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons|Bernat Desclot}} * [http://www.escriptors.cat/autors/desclotb/ Webpage dedicated to Bernat Desclot] at the AELC (''[[Associació d'Escriptors en Llengua Catalana]]''), written in English, Catalan and Spanish.
{{Authority control}}

{{For|the medal count|2011 Pan American Games medal table}} {{2011 Pan American Games}} This page contains a '''chronological summary''' of major events from the '''[[2011 Pan American Games]]''' in [[Guadalajara]], [[Mexico]]. ==Calendar== In the following calendar for the 2011 Pan American Games, each blue box represents an event competition, such as a qualification round, on that day. The yellow boxes represent days during which medal-awarding finals for a sport are held. The number in each box represents the number of finals that will be contested on that day.{{Cite web|title=XVI Pan American Games Guadalajara 2011 -Sports Calendar|url=http://www.guadalajara2011.org.mx/documentos/deportes/calendario-v4.6-en.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=Guadalajara Organizing Committee|accessdate=May 25, 2011}} {{2011 Pan American Games Calendar}} ==Day 1 – October 14 (Opening ceremony)== ; [[File:Olympic Rings Icon.svg|30px|alt=|link=]] [[2011 Pan American Games opening ceremony|Opening ceremony]]: *Starting at 8:00 pm [[Central Time Zone (North America)|CDT]] ([[UTC−6]]), the three-hour opening ceremony was attended by 50,000 spectators. The spectacle was directed by production company [[Five Currents]], and the Pan American Cauldron was lit by former Mexican diver [[Paola Espinosa]].{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/article/1070461--pan-am-games-open-with-pomp-pageantry?bn=1 |title=Pan Am Games open with pomp, pageantry |date=October 14, 2011|accessdate=October 15, 2011|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]}} ==Day 2 – October 15== ;[[Image:Cycling (mountain biking) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Heather Irmiger]] of the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's cross-country|women's cross country]] event in mountain biking, becoming the first gold medalist of the games. While [[Hector Páez]] of [[Colombia at the 2011 Pan American Games|Colombia]] wins the men's event. ;[[Image:Gymnastics (rhythmic) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games|Gymnastics]] *[[Julie Zetlin]] of the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the first rhythmic gymnastics medal on offer in the individual all around competition. ;[[Image:Modern pentathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Modern pentathlon at the 2011 Pan American Games|Modern pentathlon]] *[[Margaux Isaksen]] of the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the gold medal in the women's individual event, as three other athletes along with Isaksen from [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]], [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] and [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] qualify for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, Great Britain. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] team wins four out of the five gold medals, in the process setting one Pan American Games record. Brazil wins the only other gold medal. ;[[Image:Taekwondo pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] *[[Gabriel Mercedes]] of the [[Dominican Republic at the 2011 Pan American Games|Dominican Republic]] defends his title in the men's 58 kg event, while [[Ivett Gonda]] of [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins the gold medal in the women's 49 kg event. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="14" | Gold Medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |rowspan="2"|[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] |[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's cross-country|Men's cross-country]] |[[Hector Páez]] |{{flagPASO|COL|2011}} | | |- |[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's cross-country|Women's cross-country]] |[[Heather Irmiger]] |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} | | |- |[[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games|Gymnastics]] |[[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's rhythmic individual all-around|Women's rhythmic individual all-around]] |[[Julie Zetlin]] |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} | | |- |[[Modern pentathlon at the 2011 Pan American Games|Modern pentathlon]] |[[Modern pentathlon at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's|Women's modern pentathlon]] |[[Margaux Isaksen]] |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} | | |- |rowspan="5"|[[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] |[[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's 100 metre butterfly|Women's 100 metre butterfly]] |[[Claire Donahue]] |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} | | |- |[[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's 400 metre individual medley|Women's 400 metre individual medley]] |[[Claire Donahue]] |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} | | |- |[[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's 4 × 100 metre freestyle relay|Women's 4 × 100 metre freestyle relay]] |[[Madison Kennedy]]
[[Elizabeth Pelton]]

freestyle]] |[[Charles Houchin]] |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} | | |- |[[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's 400 metre individual medley|Men's 400 metre individual medley]] |[[Thiago Pereira]] |{{flagPASO|BRA|2011}} | | |- |rowspan="2"|[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's 49 kg|Women's 49 kg]] |[[Ivett Gonda]] |{{flagPASO|CAN|2011}} | | |- |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's 58 kg|Men's 58 kg]] |[[Gabriel Mercedes]] |{{flagPASO|DOM|2011}} | | |} ==Day 3 – October 16== ;[[Image:Cycling (road) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Colombia at the 2011 Pan American Games|Colombian]] athletes win both gold medals in the road cycling time trial events. ;[[Image:Equestrian pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games|Equestrian]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the gold medal in the team dressage event, successfully defending their championship for the fourth straight Pan American Games. ;[[Image:Gymnastics (rhythmic) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games|Gymnastics]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] wins the group event by shocking favourites [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] for the title, in the process claiming its second straight title. ;[[Image:Modern pentathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Modern pentathlon at the 2011 Pan American Games|Modern pentathlon]] *[[Óscar Soto]] of the hosts [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] wins the gold medal in the men's individual event, as three other athletes along with Soto from [[Guatemala at the 2011 Pan American Games|Guatemala]], [[Chile at the 2011 Pan American Games|Chile]] and [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] qualify for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, Great Britain. ;[[Image:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Shooting at the 2011 Pan American Games|Shooting]] *[[Daryl Szarenszki]] wins the gold medal in the 10m air pistol event with a new Pan American record in the qualifications and finals. Dorothy Ludwig of [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins the women's event, coming back on the last shot to win by 0.1 points and qualify a spot for [[Canada at the 2012 Summer Olympics|Canada]] at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]]. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] and the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] continue their dominance in the pool with Brazil picking up three gold medals, while the United States picking up the rest with two. ;[[Image:Taekwondo pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] *[[Jhohanny Jean]] of the [[Dominican Republic at the 2011 Pan American Games|Dominican Republic]] wins the second straight gold medal for his country the men's 68 kg event, while [[Irma Contreras]] of [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] wins the gold medal in the women's 57 kg event. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="15" | Gold Medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |rowspan="2"|[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] |[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's road time trial|Men's road time trial]] |[[Marlon Alirio Perez]] |{{flagPASO|COL|2011}} | | |- |[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's road time trial|Women's road time trial]] |[[María Luisa Calle]] |{{flagPASO|COL|2011}} | | |- |[[Equestrian at the 2011 Pan American Games|Equestrian]] |[[Equestrian at the 2011 Pan American Games – Team dressage|Team dressage]] |[[Steffen Peters]]

''[[Henrique Rodrigues]]*'' |{{flagPASO|BRA|2011}} |'''[[List of Pan American Games records in swimming|PR]] | |- |rowspan="2"|[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's 57 kg|Women's 57 kg]] |[[Irma Contreras]] |{{flagPASO|MEX|2011}} | | |- |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's 68 kg|Men's 68 kg]] |[[Jhohanny Jean]] |{{flagPASO|DOM|2011}} | | |} *Athletes with a '''*''' competed in preliminaries only and received medals. ==Day 4 – October 17== ;[[Image:Cycling (track) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Colombia at the 2011 Pan American Games|Colombia]] wins the men's team pursuit, while [[Venezuela at the 2011 Pan American Games|Venezuela]] sets new Pan American Records in the men's and women's team sprints ;[[Image:Gymnastics (rhythmic) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games|Gymnastics]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] wins the 5 balls group event, while the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] and [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] pick up one gold each. ;[[Image:Rowing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Rowing at the 2011 Pan American Games|Rowing]] *[[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] wins three out of the four gold medals on offer while Cuba takes the remaining title. ;[[Image:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Shooting at the 2011 Pan American Games|Shooting]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the gold medal in the men's ([[Matthew Rawlings]]) and women's ([[Emily Caruso]]) 10 metre air rifle events. ;[[Image:Squash pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Squash at the 2011 Pan American Games|Squash]] *[[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] wins the men's and women's singles and doubles events. Colombia wins the men's singles event. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] and the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] continue their dominance in the pool as each win two gold medals. ;[[Image:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Table tennis at the 2011 Pan American Games|Table tennis]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] successfully defends the men's team title, while the [[Dominican Republic at the 2011 Pan American Games|Dominican Republic]] wins the women's team title. ;[[Image:Taekwondo pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] *[[Sebastián Crismanich]] of [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] wins the men's 80 kg event, while [[Melissa Pangotta]] of [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins the women's 67 kg event. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="14" | Gold Medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |rowspan="3"|[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] |[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's team pursuit|Men's team pursuit]] |[[Juan Arango (cyclist)|Juan Arango]]

[[Eva Brito]] |{{flagPASO|DOM|2011}} | | |- |rowspan="2"|[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's 67 kg|Women's 67 kg]] |[[Melissa Pagnotta]] |{{flagPASO|CAN|2011}} | | |- |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's 80 kg|Men's 80 kg]] |[[Sebastián Crismanich]] |{{flagPASO|ARG|2011}} | | |} ==Day 5 – October 18== ;[[Image:Cycling (track) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] breaks the Pan American Games record twice en route to a gold medal performance. [[Lisandra Guerra]] of [[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] wins the women's individual sprint. ;[[Image:Gymnastics (rhythmic) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Image:Gymnastics (trampoline) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Gymnastics at the 2011 Pan American Games|Gymnastics]] *[[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins both golds in the trampoline competition, while Brazil sweeps the gold medals in the group event as it wins the 3 ribbons + 2 hoops event. The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] and [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] also picked up one gold medal each in the individual apparatus finals in rhythmic gymnastics, as that event came to a close. ;[[Image:Rowing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Rowing at the 2011 Pan American Games|Rowing]] *[[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] and [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] each pick up two gold medals while [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] pick up the only other gold medal on offer. ;[[Image:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Shooting at the 2011 Pan American Games|Shooting]] *[[Guatemala at the 2011 Pan American Games|Guatemala]] wins its first gold medal in the men's 50 meter pistol event, while the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the women's trap. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *[[Brett Fraser]] wins the [[Cayman Islands at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cayman Islands]] first ever Pan American Games gold medal by setting a new Pan American Games record in the men's 200 meter freestyle event. The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the other four gold medals that were awarded today. ;[[Image:Taekwondo pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] *[[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] wins both events today (the men's +80 and women's +67 kg classes), as taekwondo competitions also come to a close. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="14" | Gold Medalists |- !Sport !Event !Competitor(s) !{{tooltip|NOC|National Olympic Committee}} !{{tooltip|Rec|Record}} !{{tooltip|Ref|Source}} |- |rowspan="2"|[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] |[[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's team pursuit|Women's team pursuit]] |[[Laura Brown (cyclist)|Laura Brown]]

[[Erika Erndl]]'' |{{flagPASO|USA|2011}} |'''[[List of Pan American Games records in swimming|GR]] | |- |rowspan="2"|[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games|Taekwondo]] |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Women's +67 kg|Women's +67 kg]] |[[Glenhis Hernández]] |{{flagPASO|CUB|2011}} | | |- |[[Taekwondo at the 2011 Pan American Games – Men's +80 kg|Men's +80 kg]] |[[Robelis Despaigne]] |{{flagPASO|CUB|2011}} | | |} ==Day 6 – October 19== ;[[Image:Badminton pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Badminton at the 2011 Pan American Games|Badminton]] *[[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins two gold medals, while [[Guatemala at the 2011 Pan American Games|Guatemala]] takes home two gold medals, as Canada tops the medal table at the conclusion of the badminton events. ;[[Image:Cycling (track) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Juan Arango (cyclist)|Juan Arango]] of [[Colombia at the 2011 Pan American Games|Colombia]] becomes the first ever [[Pan American Games]] champion in the men's omnium, while [[Hersony Canelón]] of [[Venezuela at the 2011 Pan American Games|Venezuela]] wins the men's individual sprint. ;[[Image:Equestrian pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Equestrian at the 2011 Pan American Games|Equestrian]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] sweeps the individual dressage medals ;[[Image:Rowing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Rowing at the 2011 Pan American Games|Rowing]] *[[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] takes three of five gold medals available, after previously not taking any gold medals in rowing. [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] and the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] take one gold each as the rowing competitions come to a close. ;[[Image:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Shooting at the 2011 Pan American Games|Shooting]] The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]], [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] and [[Guatemala at the 2011 Pan American Games|Guatemala]] each win one gold medal, as the latter two set final round Pan American Games records. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] continued its dominance in the pool by winning three out of five golds, while second place [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] wins one gold. [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]], [[Venezuela at the 2011 Pan American Games|Venezuela]] and [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] win one gold each the latter two winning their first gold medals of the swimming competition. ;[[Image:Synchronized swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Synchronized swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Synchronized swimming]] *[[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins the women's duet event and qualifies to compete at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, Great Britain. ;[[Image:Table tennis pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Table tennis at the 2011 Pan American Games|Table tennis]] *[[Zhang Mo (table tennis)|Zhang Mo]] of [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] and [[Liu Song (table tennis)|Liu Song]] of [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] win the gold medal in the women's and men's individual event respectively and qualify to compete at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, Great Britain. ;[[Image:Volleyball (indoor) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Volleyball at the 2011 Pan American Games|Volleyball]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] defeats [[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] in a thrilling five set gold medal match, and wins the first gold medal awarded in a team sport. ;[[Image:Wrestling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Wrestling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Wrestling]] *[[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] wins all four gold medals available in [[Greco-Roman wrestling]] today. {| class="wikitable" |- ! The USA men set a 24 arrows Pan American record during the semifinals as well. [[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] took the bronze medal in both events. ;[[Image:Volleyball (beach) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Beach volleyball at the 2011 Pan American Games|Beach volleyball]] *The [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazilian]] pair of [[Larissa França]] and [[Juliana Felisberta]] win the women's tournament. ;[[Image:Cycling (BMX) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Connor Fields]] of the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the men's bmx event, while [[Mariana Pajón]] of [[Colombia at the 2011 Pan American Games|Colombia]] wins the women's event. ;[[Image:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Shooting at the 2011 Pan American Games|Shooting]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins both gold medals on offer today. ;[[Image:Squash pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Squash at the 2011 Pan American Games|Squash]] *[[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins the women's team event, while [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] wins the men's team event. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] continues its dominance in the pool by winning two gold medals. [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]], the distant runner-up also takes two gold medals. ;[[Image:Synchronized swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Synchronized swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Synchronized swimming]] *[[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] completes the sweep in synchronized swimming by winning the team event. ;[[Image:Tennis pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Tennis at the 2011 Pan American Games|Tennis]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] and [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] win the women's singles and doubles events respectively, while [[Ana Paula de la Penã]] and [[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] of [[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] become the first Pan American Games Champion in [[Tennis at the 2011 Pan American Games – Mixed Doubles|Mixed Doubles]] tennis since 1995. ;[[Image:Wrestling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Wrestling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Wrestling]] *[[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] continued its dominance in [[Greco-Roman wrestling]] by taking three of four gold medals available (6 of 7 overall). Games|Beach volleyball]] *[[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] completes the sweep of the beach volleyball gold medals. ;[[Image:Cycling (road) pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Cycling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cycling]] *[[Marc de Maar]] of the [[Netherlands Antilles at the 2011 Pan American Games|Netherlands Antilles]] wins the men's road race competing under the [[Pan American Sports Organization#Flag|Pan American Sports Organization Flag]], while [[Arlenis Sierra]] leads [[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] to a sweep in the women's road race. ;[[Image:Racquets pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Racquetball at the 2011 Pan American Games|Racquetball]] *[[Mexico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Mexico]] wins three out of four gold medals available while the [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the only other gold medal on offer. ;[[Image:Shooting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Racquetball at the 2011 Pan American Games|Shooting]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins two gold medals, finishing the competition with ten of the fifteen gold medals available. Cuba picks up the only other gold medal won today. ;[[Image:Swimming pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Swimming at the 2011 Pan American Games|Swimming]] *The final events of the swimming competition were held as the open water swimming competition for men and women were held in [[Puerto Vallarta]]. [[Cecilia Biagioli]] of [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] and [[Richard Weinberger]] of [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] win the women's and men's events respectively. ;[[Image:Tennis pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Tennis at the 2011 Pan American Games|Tennis]] *[[Robert Farah Maksoud|Robert Farah]] of [[Colombia at the 2011 Pan American Games|Colombia]] wins the men's singles event and the doubles event with partner [[Juan Sebastián Cabal]] as the tennis events come to a close. ;[[Image:Water skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Water skiing at the 2011 Pan American Games|Water skiing]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins the first two gold medals in water skiing, while [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] wins one gold medal. [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] wins three medals as well. ;[[Image:Wrestling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Wrestling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Wrestling]] *[[Carol Huynh]] of [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] defends her title she won four years ago in at the [[2007 Pan American Games]], while [[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] continues its dominance in wrestling by winning two out of the four women's freestyle gold medals. [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] and [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] who placed third and fourth respectively in the team event qualify a full team to compete at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London, Great Britain (the United States and Canada have already qualified). ;[[Image:Handball pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Handball at the 2011 Pan American Games|Handball]] ;[[Image:Sailing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Sailing at the 2011 Pan American Games|Sailing]] *All nine sailing events come to a close, with [[Brazil at the 2011 Pan American Games|Brazil]] taking five gold medals, [[Argentina at the 2011 Pan American Games|Argentina]] winning two, [[Chile at the 2011 Pan American Games|Chile]] and [[Puerto Rico at the 2011 Pan American Games|Puerto Rico]] winning one gold medal each. ;[[Image:Softball pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Softball at the 2011 Pan American Games|Softball]] *The [[United States at the 2011 Pan American Games|United States]] wins its record seventh straight gold medal, while [[Canada at the 2011 Pan American Games|Canada]] takes silver and [[Cuba at the 2011 Pan American Games|Cuba]] takes bronze. ;[[Image:Triathlon pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Triathlon at the 2011 Pan American Games|Triathlon]] ;[[Image:Water skiing pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Water skiing at the 2011 Pan American Games|Water skiing]] ;[[Image:Weightlifting pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Weightlifting at the 2011 Pan American Games|Weightlifting]] ;[[Image:Wrestling pictogram.svg|30px]] [[Wrestling at the 2011 Pan American Games|Wrestling]] {| class="wikitable" |- !
