{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=January 2012}} {{more citations needed|date=January 2012}} }} {{Infobox journal | title = The Classical Journal | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | former_name = | abbreviation = Class. J. | bluebook = | discipline = Classics | peer-reviewed = | language = English | editor = | publisher = [[Classical Association of the Middle West and South]] | country = United States | history = 1905 to present | frequency = Quarterly | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSNlabel = | ISSN = 0009-8353 | eISSN = | CODEN = | JSTOR = 00098353 | LCCN = | OCLC = | website = http://cj.camws.org/ | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | boxwidth = }} '''''The Classical Journal''''' (''CJ'') is a quarterly [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] of [[classical studies]] published by the [[Classical Association of the Middle West and South]].Nigel Nicholson, [http://www.camws.org/CJ/nicholson.pdf "A Century of the Classical Association of the Pacific Northwest"], ''CJ'' 104.2 (2008/09) 165–174. == Print edition == The journal currently has about 2300 subscribers, including approximately 700 libraries and research institutions.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} == History == As described by [[JSTOR]]:[https://www.jstor.org/journal/classicalj ''The Classical Journal'', JSTOR]. Accessed 2012-01-19.
''The Classical Journal'' publishes scholarly articles on Greek and Latin language and literature and on all other aspects of classical studies, together with book reviews. Its Forum section features articles devoted to pedagogy. The journal has been published continuously since 1905; over the years the number of issues per volume has varied, but it is now fixed at four.
The [[editor-in-chief]] is elected by the membership of the organization for a five-year term (renewable once). As of 2016, the current editor-in-chief is Antony Augoustakis ([[University of Illinois]]). Previous editors have been: {{columns-list|colwidth=35em| * Arthur Fairbanks (University of Chicago) 1905-1907 * Gordon J. Laing (University of Chicago) 1905-1908 * A. G. Laird (University of Wisconsin) 1907-1909 * Frank J. Miller (University of Chicago) 1908-1928 * Arthur T. Walker (University of Kansas) 1909-1932 * Roy C. Flickinger (University of Iowa) 1928-1933 * J. O. Lofberg (Oberlin College) (died November 10, 1932) * Walter Miller (University of Missouri) 1933-1935 * Eugene Tavenner (Washington University) 1935-1945 * Norman J. DeWitt (Washington University) 1945-1950 * Clyde Murley (Northwestern University) 1950-1955 * Phillip DeLacy (Washington University) 1955-1956 * Norman T. Pratt, Jr. (Indiana University) 1956-1961 * W. Robert Jones (Ohio State University) 1961-1968 * Roy Arthur Swanson (University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee) 1968-1973 * Harold D. Evjen (University of Colorado) 1973-1977 * Ernst A. Fredricksmeyer (University of Colorado) 1973-1976 * Hunter R. Rawlings, III (University of Colorado) 1977-1983 * W. W. de Grummond (Florida State University) 1983-1991 * John Miller (University of Virginia) 1991-1998 * Peter Knox (University of Colorado) 1998-2005Herbert W. Benario, The Classical Association of the Middle West and South: A History of the First Eighty Years. Classical Association of the Middle West and South, Greenville SC, 1989). * S. Douglas Olson (University of Minnesota) 2005-2010 * Laurel Fulkerson (Florida State University) 2010-2016 * Antony Augoustakis (University of Illinois) 2016-http://cj.camws.org/editors.php }} == Listserv and website == In May 2007, ''The Classical Journal'' began delivering online-exclusive [[book review]]s, professional announcements, and supplemental material through the [[University of Minnesota]]'s [[LISTSERV]].{{cite web |url=http://lists.umn.edu/cgi-bin/wa?A0=CJ-ONLINE |title=CJ-ONLINE Archives |publisher=[[University of Minnesota]] |date= |accessdate=2012-01-19}} Book reviews and the Online Forum are indexed at the journal's website. == Ancestry of doctoral degrees wiki == The website also houses DIADOCHOI, a Wiki-style searchable database dedicated to the ancestry of doctoral degrees in classical studies and closely related fields.{{cite web |url=http://classicaljournal.org/diadochoi.php |title=Genealogy of Classics |publisher=The Classical Journal |date= |accessdate=2012-01-19}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://cj.camws.org/}} * [https://www.jstor.org/journal/classicalj ''The Classical Journal''] on [[JSTOR]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Classical Journal, The}} [[Category:Publications established in 1905]] [[Category:Classics journals]] [[Category:Quarterly journals]] [[Category:English-language journals]]

{{other uses|Soul (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Sargentwyndhams.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''The Wyndham Sisters,'' by [[John Singer Sargent]], 1899 ([[Metropolitan Museum]])]] '''The Souls''' were a small, loosely-knit but distinctive social group in [[United Kingdom|England]], from 1885 to the turn of the century. If their children are included, the group lasted up to about 1920. Their members included many of the most distinguished English politicians and intellectuals. The group formed as a response to the damper on social life caused by the political tension of the [[Irish Government Bill 1886|Irish Home Rule]] debate. Existing social circles were rent by angry arguments between proponents and opponents of the [[William Ewart Gladstone|Gladstone]] ministry's efforts in 1886 to bring about full [[Home Rule]]. Many people in society wanted a [[Salon (gathering)|salon]] where they could meet without fighting about politics. [[Wilfrid Scawen Blunt]] was a member of the group and gave a good, general description of the aims and objectives of its members, and above all, what they wanted to avoid.
In my disappointment about Egypt I turned with redoubled zest to my social pleasures of the year before, and at this time saw much of that interesting group of clever men and pretty women known as the Souls, than whom no section of London Society was better worth frequenting, including as it did all that there was most intellectually amusing and least conventional. It was a group of men and women bent on pleasure, but pleasure of a superior kind, eschewing the vulgarities of racing and card-playing indulged in by the majority of the rich and noble, and looking for their excitement in romance and sentiment. Wilfrid Scawen Blunt, ''My Diaries; Being a Personal Narrative of Events 1888–1914''. Part One: 1888–1900 (New York: Knopf, 1923), p. 53.
The name of the group was bestowed by [[Lord Charles Beresford]], who is quoted as having said: "You all sit and talk about each other's souls — I shall call you the 'Souls'". Among the original Souls were: * [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston]] * [[Arthur Balfour]] * [[Margot Asquith]] * [[St John Brodrick, 1st Earl of Midleton|St. John Brodrick]] * [[Hugo Charteris, 11th Earl of Wemyss|Hugo Charteris, Lord Elcho]] * [[Mary Constance Wyndham|Mary Charteris, Lady Elcho]] * [[Alfred Lyttelton]] * [[Percy Wyndham (1835–1911)|Percy Wyndham]] * Madeline Wyndham * [[George Wyndham]] * [[Henry Cust|Henry 'Harry' Cust]] * Emmeline 'Nina' Cust * [[William Grenfell, 1st Baron Desborough]] * [[Ethel Fane|Ethel 'Ettie' Grenfell, Lady Desborough]]{{cite news|title=Revelations of Ettie Desborough, an Edwardian A-lister|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1041844/Revelations-Ettie-Desborough--Edwardian-A-lister.html|accessdate=1 February 2016|work=Mail OnLine|date=8 August 2008}} * [[Robert Windsor-Clive, 1st Earl of Plymouth]] * Alberta 'Gay' Windsor-Clive, Lady Windsor * [[Henry White (diplomat)|Henry White]], the U.S. diplomat * [[Violet Manners, Duchess of Rutland]], and her daughter by Cust, [[Lady Diana Cooper|Diana]] Also prominent in The Souls were the five Wyndhams (children of [[Percy Wyndham (1835–1911)|Percy Wyndham]]): [[George Wyndham|George]], a politician and writer; [[Guy Percy Wyndham|Guy Percy]], a soldier; Madeline, who married [[Charles Adeane]]; [[Mary Constance Wyndham|Mary]], who married [[Hugo Charteris, 11th Earl of Wemyss|Lord Elcho]]; and Pamela, who married [[Edward Tennant, 1st Baron Glenconner|Edward Tennant]], Margot Asquith's brother. [[John Singer Sargent]] painted a joint portrait of the three Wyndham sisters, as well as an individual portrait of Henry White's wife, Margaret. This original group of Souls reached its zenith in the early 1890s, and had faded out as a coherent clique by 1900. ==The Coterie== {{main|The Coterie}} [[The Coterie]] was often considered as the second generation of The Souls. They were a mix of aristocrats, politicians and art-lovers. They were patrons of artists of the time, including [[Edward Burne-Jones]] and [[James Abbott McNeill Whistler|James Whistler]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Abdy, Jane and Charlotte Gere. ''The Souls''. London : Sidgwick & Jackson, 1984. {{ISBN|0-283-98920-3}} *Ellenberger, Nancy W. ''Balfour’s World: Aristocracy and Political Culture at the Fin de Siècle''. Woodbridge: Boydell & Brewer, 2015. {{ISBN|978 1 78327 037 8}} *[[Angela Lambert|Lambert, Angela]]. ''Unquiet Souls: The Indian Summer of the British Aristocracy, 1880–1918''. London: Macmillan, 1984. *[[Allan Nevins|Nevins, Allan]]. ''Henry White: Thirty Years of American Diplomacy''. New York: Harper & Brothers, 1930. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Souls, The}} [[Category:Social history of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Edwardian era]]

page.title: Timeline of the Casey Anthony case

revision.text:
{{Main article|Death of Caylee Anthony}} The '''timeline of the Casey Anthony case''' chronicles the events surrounding the [[Death of Caylee Anthony|death of Caylee Marie Anthony]] and the trial of her mother, Casey Anthony.
==2008== June 9, 2008 – Casey Anthony and her daughter, Caylee, move out of Casey's parents, Cindy and George Anthony's home, and in with her ex-boyfriend, Ricardo Morales, and friend, Amy Huizenga.<ref name=DiscoveryTimeline>[http://investigation.discovery.com/blogs/criminal-report/casey_anthony_full_coverage/timeline/caylee_anthony_timeline.html Discovery Channel Casey Anthony Timeline], [[Discovery Communications]], see link to relevant dated page. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728093729/http://investigation.discovery.com/blogs/criminal-report/casey_anthony_full_coverage/timeline/caylee_anthony_timeline.html |date=July 28, 2011 }}</ref>
June 15, 2008 – Caylee is videotaped visiting an assisted living facility with grandmother Cindy Anthony that morning, who is visiting her father.<ref name=cfnews13timeline>[http://www.cfnews13.com/casey-anthony-timeline The Timeline in The Case Against Casey], [[Central Florida News 13]].</ref> Cindy swims with Caylee in the Anthonys' pool later that day, afterwards removing the ladder and closing the gate.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
June 16, 2008 – Caylee is last seen alive at the Anthony family residence. According to the defense, Caylee drowned in the family's above-ground swimming pool sometime during this day and both Casey and George Anthony panicked upon finding the body and covered up her death.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/><ref name=cfnews13timeline/><ref name="ClosingArg">[http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-03/justice/florida.casey.anthony.trial_1_casey-anthony-caylee-jurors?_s=PM:CRIME "Prosecution, defense offer closing arguments in Casey Anthony trial"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121010002626/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-03/justice/florida.casey.anthony.trial_1_casey-anthony-caylee-jurors?_s=PM%3ACRIME |date=2012-10-10 }}, July 3, 2011: Ashley Hayes, ''CNN Cable News Network''. Retrieved July 7, 2011.</ref> The timeline of that day follows:
* 7:00 a.m. Cindy Anthony testified that she left for work a few minutes before 7:00 a.m. while everyone in the home was still asleep.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 7:52 a.m. Activity from Casey Anthony's password-protected account on MySpace and research for "shot girls" costumes for Tony Lazarro's night club events.<ref name=Pipitone>{{cite news|last1=Pipitone|first1=Tony|title=Cops, prosecutors botched Casey Anthony evidence|url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/Cops-prosecutors-botched-Casey-Anthony-evidence/17495808|agency=WKMG Local 6|date=November 20, 2012}}</ref> * 7:56 a.m. AIM account was used to chat on the computer.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 12:50 p.m. According to George Anthony, Caylee departed with Casey by car around 12:50 p.m. with backpacks on their shoulders. (Note: Although George testified that Casey and Caylee left the house at 12:50, there is further computer activity on the home computer associated with Casey's account and her cell phone pings do not leave the area of the Anthony family home until 4:11 pm.)<ref name=Pipitone/> * 1:39 p.m. Activity associated with Casey's AIM, MySpace, and Facebook accounts at 1:39 p.m. on the home computer. The last browser activity during that session is at 1:42 p.m.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 1:44 p.m. Casey calls friend Amy Huizenga.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 2:21 p.m. Call with Amy Huizenga ends.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 2:30 p.m. George Anthony testified that he left the home at this time to go to work. * 2:49 p.m. Casey Anthony's cellphone connects with a tower nearest to the home, and the Anthony family's desktop computer is activated by someone using a password-protected account Casey Anthony used.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 2:51 p.m. A Google search is made for the term "fool-proof suffocation," misspelling the last word as "suffication". The user clicks on an article criticizing pro-suicide websites that promote "foolproof" ways to die.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 2:52 p.m. Activity on MySpace.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 2:52 p.m. Casey answers phone call from Jesse Grund. He describes this conversation as "abnormal", where Casey stated to him that her parents were divorcing and she had to find a new place to live.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 3:04 p.m. Casey disconnected the phone call from Jesse Grund to take an incoming call from George Anthony. According to the defense, the 26-second call from her father took place as soon as he got to work to tell her "I took care of everything," telling her he disposed of the body and warning her not to tell her mother about the child's death.<ref name=Pipitone/> * 3:34 p.m. Casey made a phone call to her boyfriend, Tony Lazarro. Unanswered.<ref name=Pipitone/> * Between 4:10 and 4:14 p.m. Casey made six unanswered phone calls to her mother.<ref name="Van Sustren">{{cite news|last1=Van Sustren|first1=Greta|title=Phone Log: What Caylee's Mom's Calls Could Reveal in Search for Missing Tot|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/08/13/phone-log-what-caylee-mom-calls-could-reveal-in-search-for-missing-tot.html|work=On the Record|agency=Fox News|date=August 12, 2008}}</ref> * 4:11 p.m. Casey's cellphone pings indicate it was at or near the house until she headed toward Lazzaro's apartment at 4:11 p.m. when she leaves for Tony Lazzaro's apartment. * 7:54 p.m. She and Lazzaro are seen entering and walking around casually at a [[Blockbuster video]] store. Caylee is not with them.<ref name="Discovery7/15-21">[http://investigation.discovery.com/blogs/criminal-report/casey_anthony_full_coverage/timeline/june15-june21/june15-june21.html "Timeline of Events : Casey Anthony : Caylee Anthony" July 15-21] (2011), Discovery Communications. {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713100006/http://investigation.discovery.com/blogs/criminal-report/casey_anthony_full_coverage/timeline/june15-june21/june15-june21.html |date=2011-07-13 }}</ref>
June 17, 2008 – George and Cindy Anthony notice that the gate to the swimming pool is open and the ladder is next to the pool.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/><ref name=Lohr>David Lohr, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/24/cindy-anthony-casey-anthony_n_884061.html#s294277&title=Casey_Anthony_Personal Casey Anthony's Mom: Ladder Was Left Outside The Pool], Huffington Post, June 24, 2011.</ref>
June 20, 2008 – Casey Anthony is captured in various photos partying at the Fusion nightclub and participating in a "hot body contest".<ref name="timeline ap"/><ref>Jacqui Goddard,[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1390881/Mother-dead-Caylee-Anthony-modelled-hot-body-contest-days-disappeared-Casey-Anthony.html "Room-mates describe 'fun party girl' Casey Anthony modelling in 'hot body' contest four days after daughter Caylee disappeared"], [[Daily Mail]], May 26, 2011.</ref>
June 23, 2008 - Anthony Lazzaro testified that he helped Anthony break into the shed at her parents' home to take gas cans for Casey's car, which had run out of gas. Lazarro said he watched Casey open the trunk of her car. Although he did not see the inside of the trunk, he said there was no odor that he could detect.<ref name=Hayes>{{cite news|last1=Hayes|first1=Ashley|title=Father quizzed about missing gas cans in Casey Anthony trial|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/05/26/florida.casey.anthony.trial/|agency=CNN|date=May 26, 2011}}</ref>
June 24, 2008 - George Anthony called police to report the break-in and report the gas cans missing. Later this day, he saw Casey at the Anthony residence and confronted her about taking them. George said that when he went to get them out of his daughter's car, she ran past him, quickly opened the trunk and retrieved the gas cans herself, yelling, "Here's your fucking gas cans!" George testified that he smelled gasoline in the car, but did not detect any other odors.<ref name=Hayes/>
June 30, 2008 – Casey's car is towed from a parking lot after being there for several days; her purse and a child's car seat are found in the car's back seat.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
July 2, 2008 – Casey gets a tattoo on her back saying "Bella Vita" which means "beautiful life" in Italian.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
July 15, 2008 – George and Cindy Anthony pick up Casey's car from the impound yard. George Anthony observes a strong odor emanating from the vehicle. An inspection of the car trunk reveals a plastic bag containing trash. Distressed because Casey has not brought Caylee home in a month, Cindy tracks down and meets with Amy Huizenga who takes Cindy to the apartment where Casey is staying and makes Casey come home.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/> Casey tells her parents that she hasn't seen Caylee in a month and that a babysitter named Zenaida Fernandez Gonzalez ("Zanny") may have kidnapped her. [[Cindy Anthony]] immediately calls 911 and reports her granddaughter Caylee missing.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,391001,00.html "Missing Florida Girl's Grandmother Asks Police to Arrest Daughter for 'Grand Theft' in 911 Call"], [[Fox News Channel]], July 25, 2008.</ref>
July 16, 2008 – Police investigators discover Casey Anthony has been lying about her place of employment and where she says her nanny lives. As a result, Casey is arrested and charged with [[child neglect]], making false official statements, and obstructing an investigation.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/><ref name=cfnews13timeline/><ref>Barbara Liston, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/25/us-crime-anthony-idUSTRE74O0CL20110525 Casey Anthony lied and killed daughter: prosecutor], [[Reuters]], May 25, 2011.</ref>
July 17, 2008 – Casey appears in court, during which time the judge denies bail, saying she showed a "woeful disregard for the welfare of her child." The policemen from the Sheriff's Office search Casey's car and takes several items of evidence.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
July 18, 2008 – Casey Anthony hires Jose Baez as her legal attorney.<ref>[http://www.wesh.com/casey-anthony-extended-coverage/timeline.html?qs=page=1;sort=ascending;clickAction=paginate;pageNumber=1 Casey Anthony Timeline, page 1], [[WESH]].</ref> who writes a letter to Orange County Sheriff's Office about Casey's willingness to cooperate with law enforcement.<ref>[http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/files/casey_anthony_attorney_letter_to_sheriff.pdf June 21, 2008 Jose Baez letter to Orange County Sheriff's Office ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117153131/http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/files/casey_anthony_attorney_letter_to_sheriff.pdf |date=January 17, 2009 }}</ref>
July 22, 2008 – Because of police testimony about allegedly incriminating evidence from the car, Circuit Court Judge [[Stan Strickland]] sets Casey Anthony's bail at $500,000.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
July 29, 2008 – Judge denies defense motion to ban the release to the media all jailhouse recordings, 911 tapes and visitor logs.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/> [[Freedom of information legislation (Florida)|Florida public records law]] mandates record requests by media be honored promptly.<ref>Amy L. Edwards, [http://www.fsne.org/sunshine/2009/news/orlando/ Florida laws open book on Casey Anthony's life], Florida Society of News Editors newsletter, March 15, 2009.</ref> Over the next three years thousands of pages of audio, video, forensic information and legal documents detailing the criminal investigations will be released.<ref>Other major releases of documents occurred on July 24, August 26, September 12, September 23, September 29, October 24, 2008; January 22, June 19, August 25, September 29, October 9, 2009; February 16, April 23, November 2, 2010. For details see [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/march/219927/ Casey Anthony documents archive - Evidence released in Caylee Anthony search and discovery] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909004731/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/march/219927/ |date=2011-09-09 }} (and motions related to that evidence) from [[Central Florida News 13]] and [http://investigation.discovery.com/blogs/criminal-report/casey_anthony_full_coverage/files*/caylee_anthony_files.html Miscellaneous documentary evidence released by the state from 2008] from the [[Discovery Channel]].</ref>
August 5, 2008 – The State Attorney's Office files formal charges against Casey Anthony for one felony count of child neglect.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
August 8, 2008 – [[WFTV]] reports that investigators suspect Caylee may have drowned in the family swimming pool on June 16.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
August 11, 12, 13 - Meter reader Roy Kronk reports suspicious bag to police.<ref>Bianca Prieto and Walter Pacheco, [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2009-01-14/news/casey14_1_kronk-sheriff-office-angelo-nieves Orange County meter reader discusses Casey Anthony case on 'Good Morning America'], Orlando Sentinel, January 14, 2009.</ref> A police officer meets Kronk at the scene and Kronk tells him he had seen a skull and bones in a bag. However, the officer was rude and conducted only a cursory search.<ref>Bianca Prieto, [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2009-04-11/news/cain11_1_cain-kronk-caylee-remains Deputy in Caylee case faces firing], Orlando Sentinel, April 11, 2009.</ref>
August 21, 2008 – After [[bail bondsman]] Leonard Padilla pays Casey Anthony's $500,000 bail<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/> she is fitted with an electronic monitoring device and released.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/><ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223151928/http://www.cfnews13.com/News/Local/2008/8/21/casey_anthony_released_from_jail.html|archivedate=December 23, 2008|url=http://www.cfnews13.com/News/Local/2008/8/21/casey_anthony_released_from_jail.html|title=Casey Anthony released from jail|publisher=Central Florida News 13|date=August 21, 2008}}</ref>
August 29, 2008 – Casey Anthony is arrested again on charges of writing four checks worth nearly $650 on Amy Huizenga's checking account without permission.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,414021,00.html#ixzz1Skf47ZfG Caylee's Mother Casey Anthony Back in Jail, Bond Withdrawn], [[Fox News Channel]], August 30, 2008.</ref><ref name=Karas>Beth Karas, [http://articles.cnn.com/2010-01-25/justice/florida.casey.anthony.court_1_george-and-cindy-anthony-caylee-check-fraud?_s=PM:CRIME Casey Anthony pleads guilty in check fraud case], [[CNN]], January 25, 2010.</ref> Orange County police said the charges are "unrelated to the investigation."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/08/29/caylee.arrest/index.html|title=Missing girl's mom taken into custody|publisher=CNN|date=August 30, 2008|accessdate =August 30, 2008}}</ref> Prosecutors offer Casey a limited immunity deal related to "the false statements given to law enforcement about locating her child." She refuses it soon after.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/> (The offer is renewed on August 25<ref>[http://www.wftv.com/download/2008/0829/17335521.pdf "Immunity offer email from Linda Drane Burdick to Jose Baez"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905024207/http://www.wftv.com/download/2008/0829/17335521.pdf |date=2011-09-05 }} (PDF). [[WFTV]], August 29, 2008.</ref> and again refused.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,414844,00.html Time Runs Out on Deal for Missing Orlando Tot's Mother, Police Say No More Charges Yet], Fox News Channel, September 02, 2008.</ref>)
September 5, 2008 – Casey Anthony's parents post a $500,000 bond and she is released from county jail into their custody after being fitted with an electronic tracking device.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-casey0608sep06,0,5244190.story|title=Caylee's mom goes home again|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=September 6, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913174451/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-casey0608sep06%2C0%2C5244190.story|archivedate=September 13, 2008|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/CRIME/09/05/fla.missing.girl/index.html|title=Caylee's mom gets out of jail again|date=September 5, 2008|publisher=CNN}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-caylee0508sep05,0,7306870.story|title=Casey Anthony makes bail, going home today|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=September 5, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415155412/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/orange/orl-caylee0508sep05%2C0%2C7306870.story|archivedate=April 15, 2009|df=}}</ref>
September 6, 2008 – Deputies seize a handgun from the trunk of George Anthony's car because having a gun on the property violates Casey's bail.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/> George says he planned to use it to force Casey's friends to tell him what happened to Caylee.<ref>Barbara Liston, [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/29/us-crime-anthony-idUSTRE75M60020110629 Looking for answers, Casey Anthony's father bought gun], [[Reuters]], June 29, 2011</ref>
September 10, 2008 – The whole family allegedly refuses to take a lie detector test offered by both the [[FBI]] and local authorities.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,421561,00.html Caylee's Family Refused Offer to Take Lie Detector Test], Fox News Channel, September 12, 2008.</ref>
September 15–16, 2008 – Casey Anthony turns herself in on new check fraud charges, fraudulent use of identification, and petty theft.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/> She is released the next day on $1,250 bond, and again fitted with an electronic tracking device.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
September 25, 2008 – Zenaida Fernandez-Gonzalez, the woman Casey Anthony reportedly named as an alleged baby sitter and suspect in the case, files a defamation lawsuit against her.<ref name=Escherich>{{cite web|first=Katie |last=Escherich|url=http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/story?id=6448060 |title=Timeline: Caylee Anthony Case Captivates Country |publisher=ABC News|date= December 12, 2008|accessdate=July 5, 2011}}</ref>
October 14, 2008 – Casey Anthony is indicted by a [[grand jury]] on charges of first degree murder, aggravated child abuse, aggravated manslaughter of a child, and four counts of providing false information to police. She is arrested later that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2008-10-14/justice/caylee.grand.jury_1_caylee-anthony-murder-indictment-capital-murder|title=Caylee's mom named in murder indictment|publisher=CNN|date=October 14, 2008|accessdate=July 5, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120701121651/http://articles.cnn.com/2008-10-14/justice/caylee.grand.jury_1_caylee-anthony-murder-indictment-capital-murder|archivedate=July 1, 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>[http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/files/grand_jury_indictment.pdf Copy of Casey Anthony seven count indictment], [[Discovery Channel]] blog, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330161250/http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/files/grand_jury_indictment.pdf |date=March 30, 2012 }}</ref> Judge John Jordan orders that she be held without bond.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,438206,00.html Mother of Missing Florida Toddler Makes Initial Court Appearance on Murder Charges], [[FoxNews]], October 15, 2008.</ref> Because it is a capital crime, Casey Anthony faces possible death penalty.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/><ref> [http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/files/grand_jury_indictment.pdf Copy of Indictment], at Discovery Channel website. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330161250/http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/files/grand_jury_indictment.pdf |date=March 30, 2012 }}</ref>
October 21, 2008 – Charges of [[child neglect]] are dropped against Casey Anthony on assumption the child is dead.<ref>{{cite news|title=State drops neglect charge against Caylee's mother|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-10-22/news/casey22_1_caylee-marie-anthony-neglect|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=October 22, 2008|last=Edwards|first=Amy|accessdate=July 6, 2011}}</ref> On October 28 Casey Anthony is arraigned and pleads not guilty to all charges.<ref>[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2008/10/28/Mother_arraigned_in_Caylees_death/UPI-62741225220406/ Mother arraigned in Caylee's death], [[United Press International]], October 28, 2008.</ref>
November 8–9, 2008 – [[Texas EquuSearch]] leads hundreds of volunteers in a search of a grid for Caylee, but when nothing is found they suspend their search.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/><ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
November 15, 2008 – The Anthony family's private investigator, Dominic Casey, searches the area where Caylee's remains later are found. The search is videotaped. The family's attorney denies asking Dominic Casey to search there. The defense questioned who sent him to the area; he said that a psychic gave him the tip.<ref>[http://www.wesh.com/r/18472776/detail.html Psychic Confirms She Spoke With Dominic Casey], WESH, January 13, 2009</ref> According to the prosecution, the area was under several inches of water at the time.<ref>Jessica Hopper, [http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey-anthony-trial-video-search-body-found/story?id=13938488 Casey Anthony Trial: Video of Vain Search Where Body Later Found], [[ABC News]], June 27, 2011</ref>
December 5, 2008 – The state initially says it will not seek the death penalty against Casey Anthony.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
December 11, 2008 – After yet a fourth tip from Roy Kronk, skeletal remains of what appeared to be a small child are found one-quarter mile from the Anthony home.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/> Orange County Sheriff's Office obtains warrant and searches Anthony residence.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
December 19, 2008 – Police announce [[DNA testing]] confirms that the remains belong to Caylee Anthony.<ref name=Escherich/><ref>{{cite news|title=Remains identified as missing toddler Caylee Anthony|first=Walter|last=Pacheco|first2=Sarah|last2=Lundy|first3=Amy L.|last3=Edwards|work=Orlando Sentinel|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/breakingnews/orl-bk-caylee-anthony-body-dna-121908,0,1859200.story|date=December 19, 2008}}</ref>
== 2009 ==
January 23, 2009 – Police discover George Anthony, who had been [[text messaging]] family members, despondent and possibly under the influence of alcohol and medication in a hotel room. Police also discovered a lengthy [[suicide note]].<ref name=cfnews13timeline/><ref name=Escherich/>
January 29, 2009 – Judge [[Stan Strickland]] orders [[Casey Anthony]] to appear at all court hearings in her case.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
April 14, 2009 – The [[State of Florida]] reverses self and will seek the imposition of the [[death penalty]].<ref name=Escherich/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/breakingnews/orl-bk-casey-anthony-case-death-penalty-041309,0,1925641.story|title=State to seek death penalty in Casey Anthony case|first=Amy L.|last=Edwards|author2=Sarah Lundy|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=April 13, 2009|accessdate=April 13, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415103859/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/breakingnews/orl-bk-casey-anthony-case-death-penalty-041309%2C0%2C1925641.story|archivedate=April 15, 2009|df=}}</ref>
September 17, 2009 – [[Casey Anthony]]'s defense team files a [[motion to dismiss]] the murder charges against her because the state allegedly failed to preserve evidence in the case. The motion is denied.<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
November 24, 2009 – Defense attorneys accuse [[Texas EquuSearch]]'s Tim Miller of lying to the court in their claim that only 32 people searched in the area where Caylee's remains were eventually found and that the number was much higher.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
December 18, 2009 – Judge [[Stan Strickland]] denies a request to take the death penalty off of the table in the prosecution of [[Casey Anthony]].<ref name = DiscoveryTimeline/>
== 2010 ==
January 26, 2010 – Casey pleads guilty for 13 fraudulent check charges, takes responsibility for her actions,<ref name=cfnews13timeline/> and makes full restitution. The judge sentences her to time served.<ref name=Karas/>
April 19, 2010 – Judge [[Stan Strickland]] steps down after [[Casey Anthony]]'s defense team files a motion accusing him of having inappropriate conversations with a writer, Dave Knechel, who blogged about the case. Strickland granted the motion because the accusation would "generate renewed allegations of bias". Judge [[Belvin Perry|Belvin Perry, Jr.]] is appointed to take over the case.<ref name=DiscoveryTimeline/><ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
May 11, 2010 – Judge Perry will allow the state to seek the death penalty.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
August 14, 2010 – Cindy Anthony appears as a guest on the "Today" Show where she calls Casey a victim, and also claims she's not involved with what happened to Caylee's remains.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
August 16, 2010 – George and [[Cindy Anthony]]'s attorney, Brad Conway, steps down because he disputes a Jose Baez motion claiming Conway was given unrestricted access to documents belonging to [[Texas EquuSearch]] to which he was not given the same access.<ref name=DiscoveryTimeline/>
== 2011 ==
January 4, 2011 – Judge [[Belvin Perry|Belvin Perry, Jr.]] postpones ruling on over two dozen defense motions to exclude evidence from the trial.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20027189-504083.html Casey Anthony Update: Judge Slams Murder Defense for "Willful Violation" of Court Order], [[CBS News]], January 4, 2011.</ref> Over the next several months Perry rules for or against these various motions to exclude evidence.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/> He admonishes, and later financially sanctions, defense attorney Jose Baez for failing to turn over expert witness discovery information to prosecutors before a certain deadline.<ref>Carlin DeGuerin Miller, [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20027765-504083.html Casey Anthony Update: Defense Attorney Jose Baez Ordered to Pay $583.73 Fine], CBS News, January 7, 2011.</ref>
April 1, 2011 – After numerous outbursts by lawyers in court over what is and is not scientific evidence, Judge Perry ruled more such behavior would result in a fine of $100 per outburst, with the proceeds to go to the [[United Way of America|United Way]].<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
May 20, 2011 – After eleven days of jury selection, Judge Perry swears in a jury of five men and seven women, plus three men and two women as alternate jurors.<ref name=cfnews13timeline/>
May 24, 2011 – Trial begins in [[Orlando, Florida]]. The prosecution states Casey Anthony used duct tape to [[Asphyxia|suffocate]] Caylee Anthony. The defense contends the child actually drowned in her grandparents' swimming pool, that Casey's father George Anthony warned Casey she would be imprisoned for life for child neglect and then covered up the death; thus she failed to report the incident for 31 days. Also, because George Anthony had sexually molested Casey as a child she had a habit of hiding her pain and lying.<ref name=WFTV-May24>{{cite news|url=http://www.wftv.com/news/28001858/detail.html|title=Casey Murder Trial Brings Tears, Blame And Shame|work=WFTV Orlando|date=May 24, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528033419/http://www.wftv.com/news/28001858/detail.html|archivedate=May 28, 2011|df=}}</ref> Baez admits Casey had fabricated the story of the nanny named Zenaida Fernandez-Gonzales.<ref>Amy Pavuk, [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-07-08/news/os-casey-anthony-zenaida-deposition-20110708_1_defamation-case-casey-anthony-george-anthonyCasey Anthony: Transcript of murder trial opening statement filed in defamation case], Orlando Sentinel, July 08, 2011.</ref> Baez also questions whether Roy Kronk, who found the remains, actually removed them from elsewhere and questioned police motivations for pursuing a murder investigation.<ref name=WFTV-May24/><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/05/24/opening-statements-begin-casey-anthony-murder-trial/ Caylee Anthony's Family 'Appalled' After Casey Anthony's Attorney Blames Them for Death], Fox News Channel, May 24, 2011.</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/26/us-crime-anthony-idUSTRE74P6QZ20110526 No smell of human decay in Casey Anthony's trunk: witness], [[Reuters]], May 26, 2011.</ref> Prosecutors call George Anthony as their first witness and he denies to them having ever sexually abused his daughter Casey or covering up the death of Caylee.<ref>Walter Pacheco, [http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/defense-bombshell-caylee-anthony-drowned-in-family-swimming-1494437.html?printArticle=y Defense bombshell: Caylee Anthony drowned in family swimming pool], Orlando Sentinel, May 24, 2011.</ref>
May 25, 2011 – The prosecution calls various friends of Casey Anthony who testify about her fabricated stories during June and July 2008 of having a job and employing a nanny for Caylee. A neighbor testifies that in mid-June 2008 Casey and a boyfriend borrowed a shovel from him to dig up a bamboo root.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Christine Webb, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/251132/ Day 2: Casey Anthony's ex-boyfriend takes witness stand], Central Florida News 13, May 25, 2011.</ref>
May 26, 2011 – Former boyfriend testifies Casey told him her brother, Lee Anthony, sexually groped her. George Anthony is called back to the witness stand where he says that he did not smell decomposition in Casey's car on June 24, 2008 and states he put [[duct tape]] over a hole in one of the plastic gas cans she had returned to him.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/251968/ Day 3: Ex says Casey Anthony told him Lee tried to 'feel her up'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110802055220/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/251968/ |date=2011-08-02 }}, Central Florida News 13, May 26, 2011.</ref>
May 27, 2011 – A tow truck company manager and George Anthony testify that from their experience the smell from Casey's car resembled human decomposition.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/252672/ Day 4: George Anthony questioned about smell in Casey's car] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805124349/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/252672 |date=2011-08-05 }}, Central Florida News 13, May 27, 2011.</ref> During cross-examination, George Anthony tells Jose Baez that he did not sexually abuse Casey.<ref>[http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/2011/05/casey-anthony-trial-day-4-the-courting-of-george-anthony.html Casey Anthony Trial, Day 4], Discovery Channel, May 27, 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903063709/http://blogs.discovery.com/criminal_report/2011/05/casey-anthony-trial-day-4-the-courting-of-george-anthony.html |date=September 3, 2011 }}</ref>
May 28, 2011 – Former boyfriend testifies about Casey's normal behavior on June 16, 2008. Cindy Anthony testifies that they swam that day and that Caylee could get up the ladder into the pool. She also believed Casey worked at [[Universal Studios]] Orlando Resort and had a babysitter named Zanny.<ref>Jacqueline Fell and Amanda Evans, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/253267/ Day 5: Cindy and Casey Anthony cry at sight of Caylee's bed, playhouse], Central Florida News 13, May 28, 2011.</ref>
May 31, 2011 – Cindy Anthony says her description of Casey's car smelling "like someone died" was just a "figure of speech." She tried to get rid of the smell by spraying [[Febreze]] household odor eliminator. She says she found the pool ladder in the pool the evening of June 16. Casey's friend Amy Huizenga talks of Casey's frustration about getting help with Caylee and reveals that on June 27, Casey texted her about a dead animal on the frame of the car.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo, Kelli Cook and Christine Webb, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/254277/ Day 6: Casey Anthony jury hears 911 calls, Cindy in tears on stand] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814025450/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/may/254277 |date=2011-08-14 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 08, 2011.</ref>
June 1, 2011 – The first officers to arrive at the Anthony home on July 16, 2008 testify that they did not smell human decomposition in Casey's car and admit they did not search the other two family cars. They also testify about Casey going to [[Universal Orlando Resort]] with Casey that day, where she confessed she no longer worked there and did not have a nanny named Zenaida Fernandez-Gonzalez.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo, Kelli Cook and Christine Webb, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/254957/ Day 7: Casey Anthony's brother, Orange County deputies testify], Central Florida News 13, June 08, 2011.</ref>
June 2, 2011 – Video tapes are shown of Casey lying to her parents in jail and denying to an officer on July 16, 2008 that Caylee had drowned in the pool, as he suggested.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/255460/ Day 8: Jury sees Casey Anthony jailhouse videos, hears lies at Universal], Central Florida News 13, June 08, 2011</ref>
June 3, 2011 – Investigators describe evidence collection from Casey's car and obtaining from the towing yard the plastic garbage bag that had been in it. One investigator states he smelled [[human decomposition]].<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/256189/ Day 9: Crime scene technicians testify in Casey Anthony trial], Central Florida News 13, June 08, 2011.</ref>
June 4, 2011 – An FBI forensic scientist testifies the single hair removed from the car trunk was similar to a hair from Caylee's hair brush and had "root-banding" consistent with that from a decomposing body.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/04/us-crime-anthony-idUSTRE75323G20110604 Hair in Casey Anthony's trunk may be Caylee's: expert], [[Reuters]], June 4, 2011.</ref>
June 6, 2011 – Dr. Arpad Vass of the [[Oak Ridge National Laboratory]] describes using a gas chromatograph mass spectrometer to find signs of human decomposition and a high level of [[chloroform]] in the trunk of Casey's car. The defense challenges Vass' financial motivation and the chain of evidence.<ref name=CFNewsDay11>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/257538/ Day 11: Expert smelled death in air samples from Casey Anthony's car], Central Florida News 13, June 08, 2011.</ref><ref>Also see article about the earlier lab report: Sarah Lundy, [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-10-25/news/casey25_1_casey-anthony-decomposition-anthony-attorney FBI, Oak Ridge lab tests on Casey Anthony's car released], Orlando Sentinel, October 25, 2008.</ref>
June 7, 2011 – FBI [[forensic chemist]] confirms chloroform residue in trunk of Casey's car, but also states that household cleaning products leave traces of chloroform. A dog handler describes dog alerting to human decomposition in the trunk, as well as Caylee's playhouse.<ref name=CFNewsDay11/>
June 8, 2011 – Second dog handler says his dog smelled decomposition in back yard. Computer analysts confirm a search for "chloroform" on Casey's computer March 17, 2008 and "how to make chloroform" on March 21, 2008.<ref>Jacqueline Fell and Adam Longo, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/259019/ Day 13: Canines, computers and chloroform in Casey Anthony trial], June 09, 2011.</ref>
June 9, 2011 – [[Software analyst]] John Bradley states someone used the Anthony computer to search the website Sci-spot.com for "chloroform" 84 times on March 21, 2008. During cross-examination, he admits that automatic page reloading could account for that number and there was no way of knowing who performed the searches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news-journalonline.com/breakingnews/2011/06/novel-forensics-tool-used-in-casey-anthony-trial.html |accessdate=September 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814132210/http://www.news-journalonline.com/breakingnews/2011/06/novel-forensics-tool-used-in-casey-anthony-trial.html |archivedate=August 14, 2011 }}</ref> Investigators show photographs of the remains, including of duct tape that appears to be over the mouth area. One admits that duct tape might not originally have been on the mouth and could have shifted position as he collected remains. Casey Anthony becomes ill looking at the photographs and the jury is dismissed for the day.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/259603/ Day 14: Photos of Caylee's skull make Casey Anthony ill, court ends early] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004165750/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/259603 |date=2011-10-04 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 9, 2011.</ref>
June 10, 2011 – [[Medical examiner]] states that the death is ruled a [[homicide]] because of the delay in reporting the disappearance, the fact the body was hidden, and the existence of duct tape, but states under cross-examination she did not know how the child died.<ref>Kyle Hightower, [http://www.news-journalonline.com/news/florida/2011/06/11/prosecutors-focus-on-duct-tape-in-casey-anthony-trial.html Prosecutors focus on duct tape in Casey Anthony trial] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714062215/http://www.news-journalonline.com/news/florida/2011/06/11/prosecutors-focus-on-duct-tape-in-casey-anthony-trial.html |date=2011-07-14 }}, [[Associated Press]], June 11, 2011.</ref> Crime scene investigators describe similar maggots found in the car trunk and at the crime scene.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Dave D'Marko and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/260275/ Day 15: Jury sees shocking animation of Caylee Anthony 'becoming' skull], Central Florida News 13, June 10, 2011.</ref>
June 11, 2011 – An expert in [[forensic entomology]] states he found flies related to decomposition in the trunk of Casey's car. [[Orange County, Florida]] [[crime scene investigator]]s identify a piece of Henkel brand duct tape found at the scene and testify it is the same brand as George Anthony put on the red gas can. One states that no Henkel brand tape was found elsewhere in the Anthonys' home.<ref>Amanda Evans, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/260941/ Day 16: Bug expert compares samples in Casey Anthony's car, Caylee crime scene], Central Florida News 13, June 13, 2011.</ref>
June 13, 2011 – FBI examiner states a hair from the child's skull is consistent with but not identical to the single hair found in the trunk. FBI agent could not find any [[fingerprint]]s on duct tape found near the remains but initially did find adhesive in the shape of a heart on a corner of a piece of duct tape; later she could not find it again.<ref name=Hayes2>Ashley Hayes, [http://articles.cnn.com/2011-06-13/justice/florida.casey.anthony.trial_1_caylee-anthony-duct-tape-casey-anthony?_s=PM:CRIME Examiner: Heart-shaped adhesive found on tape covering Caylee's mouth], [[CNN]], June 13, 2011.</ref><ref>Steve Helling, [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20502254,00.html Casey Anthony Trial: Heart-Shaped Sticker Residue Found on Duct Tape], ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', June 13, 2011.</ref><ref>Jessica Hopper, [http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey_anthony_trial/casey-anthony-trial-defense-casts-Doubt-heart-stickers/story?id=13855375 Casey Anthony Trial: Defense Casts Shadow on Heart Stickers Found With Caylee's Remains], [[ABC News]], June 16, 2011.</ref>
June 14, 2011 – FBI quality assurance specialist says the hair found in trunk could have come from any member of the Anthony family.<ref name=HightowerJuly2>Kyle Hightower, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43617797/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/jurors-see-scant-evidence-casey-anthony-trial/ Jurors see scant evidence in Casey Anthony trial], [[MSNBC]], July 2, 2011.</ref> A crime scene investigator says heart shaped stickers were found in Casey's room but did not link them to the one alleged to be on the duct tape.<ref>Carlin DeGuerin Miller, [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20071136-504083.html Casey Anthony Trial Update: Heart stickers and hair evidence], CBS News, June 14, 2011 .</ref> Testimony about and photo of Casey's "Bella Vita" tattoo made on July 2, 2008.<ref>Jacqueline Fell and Adam Longo, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/262226/ Day 18: State may be done with witnesses in Casey Anthony trial], Central Florida News 13, June 15, 2011.</ref>
June 15, 2011 – Prosecution rests its case. Defense makes a motion to acquit based on insufficient evidence a murder was committed, which the judge denies based on previous case rulings.<ref>Jacqueline Fell and Adam Longo, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/262939/ Day 19: Prosecution rests, Judge [[Belvin Perry|Belvin Perry, Jr.]] denies motion to acquit Casey Anthony], Central Florida News 13, June 15, 2011.</ref>
June 16, 2011 – Defense begins its case, often recalling state witnesses for further testimony. Crime scene investigator says no blood was found in Casey's car or incriminating stains on her clothes.<ref name=CFNews13Day20>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/263696/ Day 20: Casey Anthony's defense begins case, challenges DNA evidence], Central Florida News 13, June 16, 2011.</ref> FBI analyst states no DNA evidence was found in the car or at the crime scene. She states FBI did a [[paternity test]] that showed Lee Anthony was not Caylee's father.<ref name=Hopper>Jessica Hopper, [http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey-anthony-trial-paternity-test-father-brother/story?id=13855375 Casey Anthony Trial: Defense Casts Shadow on Heart Stickers Found With Caylee's Remains ], [[ABC News]], June 16, 2011.</ref> Crime scene investigator and forensics supervisor state a heart-shaped sticker was found far from the body. An FBI forensic document examiner found no evidence of a heart shaped sticker on the duct tape found near the remains.<ref name=CFNews13Day20/><ref name=Hopper/>
June 17, 2011 – [[Forensic entomologist]] called by the defense states if there was a body in the trunk, there should have been hundreds or even thousands of blow flies trapped in the trunk as well.<ref>[http://www.clickorlando.com/news/28268516/detail.html "Casey Anthony Defense Expert Contradicts State Entomologist"], [[WKMG-TV]] Orlando, June 17, 2011.</ref>
June 18, 2011 – Defense calls a new witness, Dr. Werner Spitz, who questions the medical examiner's autopsy, including the failure to open the skull, and says there was no indication the death was a homicide. He believes the duct tape was placed on the skull after [[decomposition]] and that the crime scene photos of the position of the hair on the skull were staged, possibly by the medical examiner.<ref>Jacqueline Fell and Amanda Evans, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/265206/ Day 22: Judge threatens Casey Anthony's lawyer with contempt] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828014523/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/265206 |date=2011-08-28 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 19, 2011.</ref>
June 21, 2011 – A defense-called [[forensic botanist]] challenges the prosecution's theory of when the body was placed at the crime scene. An expert in [[analytical chemistry]] who works with Dr. Vass challenges the process of testing for the presence of chloroform.<ref>Kelli Cook, Adam Longo and Jacqueline Fell, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/266450/ Day 24: New defense expert talks DNA in Casey Anthony trial], Central Florida News 13, June 21, 2011.</ref>
June 22, 2011 – An FBI forensic examiner says no dirt from the crime scene was found on shoes at the Anthony home or a neighbor's borrowed shovel. FBI forensic toxicologist found no toxins in the hair from Caylee Anthony's skull. A scientist who worked with Dr. Vass who testifies tests did not conclusively prove there was a body in the trunk. The FBI's forensic chemist examiner could not find traces of chloroform in the car. The FBI forensics expert found no hair in the trunk liner showing signs of decomposition. She also testified the duct tape at the crime scene was dissimilar to that in the Anthony home.<ref>Kelli Cook, Adam Longo and Jacqueline Fell, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/267140/ Day 25: Another short day as Casey Anthony's defense brings in more experts], Central Florida News 13, June 23, 2011</ref>
June 23, 2011 – An FBI hair and fiber expert says only one hair from the car truck had a sign of decomposition. There is a long debate among prosecutors and defense over the reliability of "root banding." An expert in [[forensic toxicology]] testifies Dr. Vass's test "lacked organization and planning" and had "minimal standards of quality control." He also mentions that chloroform is a byproduct of chlorinated swimming pool water.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/267877/ Day 26: Cindy Anthony says she searched for 'chloroform,' not Casey], Central Florida News 13, June 23, 2011.</ref>
June 24, 2011 – Cindy Anthony is recalled to the stand where the defense shows her a photograph of Caylee on the pool ladder and she again mentions the ladder was in the pool on June 16 when she returned home from work that evening, adding that she called George to ask about it since she took out the ladder from the pool on the previous day after swimming there with Caylee. The defense also showed the jury a picture of Caylee appearing to open a sliding-glass door at her home. Cindy says Caylee was capable of opening the sliding door to the back yard and the pool.<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43523664/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/#.TmuqN2qE8SE Anthony trial: Photos show Caylee climbing into family pool], [[MSNBC]], June 24, 2011.</ref> Lee Anthony states he was not told Casey was [[pregnant]] until days before Caylee's birth. Search volunteer testifies about duct tape being used at search headquarters.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/268532/ Day 27: Cindy and Lee Anthony give tearful testimony], Central Florida News 13, June 24, 2011.</ref>
June 25, 2011 – Judge [[Belvin Perry|Belvin Perry, Jr.]] temporarily halts proceedings after defense motion to determine if Anthony was competent to proceed with trial, based on a privileged communication from [[Casey Anthony]].<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Janelle Jordan, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/269182/ Day 28: No court today after another abrupt recess in Casey Anthony trial], Central Florida News 13, June 25, 2011.</ref><ref name=CFNewsDay29>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/269830/ Day 29: Casey Anthony competent to stand trial, expert breaks down decomposition] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829141633/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/269830/ |date=2011-08-29 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 28, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.clickorlando.com/download/2011/0627/28372398.pdf Motion To Determine Competency To Proceed] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006005443/http://www.clickorlando.com/download/2011/0627/28372398.pdf |date=2011-10-06 }}, Orlando Sentinel, June 25, 2011.</ref>
June 27, 2011 – Casey Anthony is found competent to continue after [[psychological evaluation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Psychologists Determine Casey Anthony Mentally Competent|url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/28367148/detail.html|publisher=[[WKMG-TV]]|accessdate=July 6, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110630171604/http://www.clickorlando.com/news/28367148/detail.html|archivedate=June 30, 2011|df=}}</ref> June 27 also is the date the prosecution states it discussed with defense attorney Jose Baez [[software analyst]] John Bradley's post-testimony admission to prosecutors that there was only one search for chloroform, not 84.<ref>[http://www.wesh.com/r/28600305/detail.html State: Casey Defense, Court Knew Of Software Issues] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314091204/http://www.wesh.com/r/28600305/detail.html |date=2012-03-14 }}, WESH, July 19, 2011.</ref><ref>Jacqueline Fell, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/july/281721/Mistake-in-chloroform-evidence-in-Casey-Anthony-case Mistake in chloroform evidence in Casey Anthony case] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823064934/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/july/281721/Mistake-in-chloroform-evidence-in-Casey-Anthony-case |date=2011-08-23 }}, Central Florida News 13, July 19, 2011.</ref> In testimony, the lead detective admits cadaver dogs had not searched inside the Anthonys' home, or in two other Anthony cars. A professor of chemistry called by the defense says there is no scientifically valid instrument that can identify [[decomposition]],<ref name=CFNewsDay29/> that there is no consensus on what chemicals are typical of human decomposition<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-04-01/news/os-casey-anthony-science-experts-20110401_1_cindy-anthony-casey-anthony-jose-baez |title=Casey Anthony trial: Judge Perry threatens to fine squabbling attorneys|publisher=Orlando Sentinel |date=April 1, 2011 |accessdate=July 24, 2011}}</ref> and that chemical compounds identified by Dr. Vass in air samples can be found in household products and garbage. Three witnesses discuss the November 2008 videotaped search by Anthony family [[private investigator]]s in the woods where Caylee's body later was found.<ref name=CFNewsDay29/>
June 28, 2011 – A [[Texas EquuSearch]] team letter discusses their November search for Caylee of the site where the body later was found. George Anthony denies he had an affair with Krystal Holloway, borrowed money from her, or told her Caylee's death was "an accident that snowballed out of control." He admits going to her home and sending her a text message. He testifies he bought a gun to threaten Casey's friends into telling him where Caylee was, even though he knew having one violated Casey's bail. Cindy Anthony denies she sent private investigators to search the site where Caylee's body later was found; her son Lee Anthony and the case's lead detective then testify she did so, after talking to a psychic.<ref name=CFNewsDay30>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Kelli Cook, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/270422/ Day 30: Roy Kronk testifies on finding Caylee Anthony's remains] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903022639/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/270422/ |date=2011-09-03 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 28, 2011.</ref> Roy Kronk testifies about his calls to police and finding the body. He denies he told his son finding the body would make him rich and famous,<ref>Anthony Colarossi, [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-06-28/news/os-casey-anthony-trial-day-30-20110628_1_roy-kronk-casey-anthony-trial-suburban-drive Casey Anthony trial: Meter reader Roy Kronk testifies about finding remains], Orlando Sentinel, June 28, 2011.</ref> but admits he did receive $5,000 after Caylee's remains were identified.<ref name=CFNewsDay30/> Judge Perry does not allow jury to hear Casey's ex-fiancée say that Casey told him Lee had once tried to grope her while she was sleeping.<ref>Barbara Liston, [http://www.torontosun.com/2011/06/29/casey-anthony-fiance-testimony-blocked Casey Anthony fiance testimony blocked], [[Reuters]], June 29, 2011.</ref>
June 29, 2011 – Cindy Anthony says Casey's response to the media theory that Caylee drowned was "Surprise. Surprise." Baez asks George Anthony about his suicide attempt in January 2009 and the next day the judge allows the jury to see the suicide note.<ref name=CFNewsDay32>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/271083/ Day 31: George Anthony breaks down, jury hears from Kronk's son, grief expert] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110901235024/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/271083/ |date=2011-09-01 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 30, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/272093/Read-George-Anthonys-suicide-note Read George Anthony's suicide note], Central Florida News 13.</ref> Roy Kronk's son states that Kronk did say that finding [[Caylee Anthony]] would making him rich and famous. Kronk testifies about why he changed his story about lifting the skull. An expert on grief and trauma testifies that pretending nothing had happened and partying was one of many different ways people, especially young people, express grief.<ref name=CFNewsDay32/>
June 30, 2011 – Casey Anthony tells Judge Perry she does not want to testify.<ref name=Liston>Barbara Liston, [http://www.torontosun.com/2011/06/30/casey-anthony-wont-testify Casey Anthony won't testify], [[Reuters]], June 30, 2011.</ref> Perry will not allow the jury to sniff air samples from the car trunk.<ref name=HightowerJuly2/>/<ref name=CFNewsDay32b>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Christine Webb, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/271726/ Day 32: Defense rests, Casey Anthony won't testify] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904122155/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/271726/ |date=2011-09-04 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 30, 2011.</ref> Defense calls search volunteer Krystal Holloway who states that she had an affair with George Anthony. She states that George Anthony told her that Caylee's death was "an accident that snowballed out of control." Under cross-examination, she also agreed with her earlier statement to police in which she said George Anthony did not say he knew it was an accident. After Holloway steps down, Judge Perry tells jurors that her testimony could be used to impeach George Anthony's credibility, but that it is not proof of how Caylee died.<ref name=CFNewsDay32/><ref>Ashley Hayes, [http://www.kvia.com/news/28403325/detail.html Defense Rests In Casey Anthony Trial] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927075701/http://www.kvia.com/news/28403325/detail.html |date=2011-09-27 }}, [[CNN]], June 29, 2011.</ref> George, Cindy and Lee Anthony all testify that their pets had been buried in the back yard. Cindy calls it a "tradition" to wrap them in blankets and a plastic bag; duct tape was used to keep the plastic bags from opening. After this final witness, the defense rests.<ref name=Liston/> The prosecutor rebuttal begins with showing the jury photographs of Caylee's clothes and George's suicide note.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/271726/ Day 32: Defense rests, Casey Anthony won't testify] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904122155/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/june/271726/ |date=2011-09-04 }}, Central Florida News 13, June 30, 2011.</ref>
July 1, 2011 – The prosecution continues rebuttal with two representatives of Cindy Anthony's former employer explaining why their computer login system shows Cindy was at work the afternoon she said she went home early and searched her computer for information about chloroform. A police computer analyst says someone had purposely searched online for "neck + breaking." Another analyst testifies she did not find evidence that Cindy Anthony had searched certain terms she claimed to have searched. An anthropology professor is recalled to rebut a defense witness on the need to open a skull during an autopsy. The lead detective states that there were no phone calls between Cindy and George Anthony during the week of June 16, 2008, but admits he did not know that George had a second cell phone.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Christine Webb, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/july/272379/ Day 33: Testimony ends, closing arguments start Sunday] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905134911/http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/july/272379/ |date=2011-09-05 }}, Central Florida News 13, July 01, 2011.</ref>
July 3, 2011 – Judge Perry rules that during closing arguments the defense could argue there was a drowning involved in the death of Caylee because there was sufficient evidence of that, but could not argue George had sexually abused Casey.<ref>Hal Boedecker, [http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2011/07/casey-anthony-did-judge-throw-defense-a-huge-bone.html Casey Anthony: Did judge throw defense a huge bone?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904152742/http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2011/07/casey-anthony-did-judge-throw-defense-a-huge-bone.html |date=2011-09-04 }}, Orlando Sentinel, July 3, 2011.</ref> Prosecution does an hour and a half of closing arguments, offering a timeline of events and asserting that Casey intentionally [[Asphyxia|suffocate]]d Caylee to death by putting three pieces of duct tape place over her face. The alleged motive was that the child interfered with her partying lifestyle and spending time with her boyfriend. The prosecution states the defense' story that Caylee drowned and George encouraged Casey to cover up the accident made no sense. The defense counters with four hours of arguments insisting there was no proof of how Caylee died, challenging the prosecutors' most important evidence as "fantasy," and emphasizing the reasonable doubt that Casey killed Caylee. It again insists that after the child drowned, Casey panicked and George Anthony made the death look like a murder and that he was the one who put the body in the nearby woods.<ref name=Hayes/><ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo and Amanda Evans, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/july/273314/ Closing arguments continue Monday with state rebuttal in the case against Casey Anthony], Central Florida News 13, July 03, 2011.</ref>
July 4, 2011 – Prosecutors Jeff Ashton and [[Linda Drane Burdick]] present a rebuttal to the defense closing, telling jurors their forensic evidence had proved their case, while the defense made claims they did not prove. The case then goes to the jury.<ref>Jacqueline Fell, Adam Longo, Kelli Cook and Christine Webb, [http://www.cfnews13.com/article/news/2011/july/273705/ The Case Against Casey Anthony - Jury deliberations continue Tuesday], Central Florida News 13, July 05, 2011.</ref> Judge [[Belvin Perry|Belvin Perry, Jr.]] issues final instructions to the jury.<ref>[http://insession.blogs.cnn.com/2011/07/04/jury-instructions-in-the-casey-anthony-trial/ Final written jury instructions], [[CNN]], July 4, 2011.</ref>
July 5, 2011 – After about ten hours of deliberation, the jury acquits Casey Anthony of all [[felony]] charges (i.e., of [[first-degree murder]], aggravated manslaughter, and aggravated child abuse), but convicts her of all four [[misdemeanor]] charges of giving false information to a law enforcement officer.<ref name="timeline ap">[https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/timeline-in-the-casey-anthony-case/2011/07/05/gHQACqAYzH_story.html "Timeline in the Casey Anthony case"], [[Associated Press]], July 5, 2011.</ref>
July 7, 2011 – Judge Perry sentences Casey Anthony to one year in county jail and $1,000 in fines for each of the four misdemeanor counts of providing false information to a law enforcement officer. The judge orders all sentences to run [[consecutive]] to each other, with credit for time served.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20077485-504083.html?tag=contentMain;contentBody "Casey Anthony Trial Update: Casey Anthony sentenced, headed back to jail"], CBS News, July 7, 2011.</ref> Based on three years credit for [[time served]] plus additional credit for [[good conduct time|good behavior]], her release date is set for July 17, 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/07/07/florida.casey.anthony.next/index.html |title=Casey Anthony gets maximum jail time, could walk free in weeks |date=July 7, 2011 |work=[[MSNBC]] |accessdate=July 7, 2011}}</ref> Judge Perry announces he will not release the juror's names for seven days saying some people "disagree with their verdict" and "would like to take something out on them."<ref>Jamal Thalji, [http://www.tampabay.com/news/courts/casey-anthony-jurors-names-will-be-released-8212-but-not-today/1179295 Casey Anthony jurors' names will be released—but not today], [[St. Petersburg Times]], July 8, 2011.</ref>
July 13, 2011 - [[Texas EquuSearch]], which assisted in the search for Caylee, sues [[Casey Anthony]] for the costs of the search.<ref>Barbara Liston, [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43116818 Search group sues Casey Anthony for costly efforts] [[MSNBC]]/[[Reuters]], July 13, 2011.</ref>
July 15, 2011 – Casey Anthony [[appeals]] convictions of providing false information to a law enforcement officer.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey-anthony-appeals-conviction-lying-police/story?id=14080086 "Casey Anthony Appeals Lying Conviction"], [[ABC News]], July 15, 2011.</ref>
July 17, 2011 – Casey Anthony is released from jail at 12:10 AM, with $537.68 in cash.<ref name="Lohr" />
July 19, 2011 – Prosecutors write a letter responding to a [[New York Times]] article about alleged withholding of [[exculpatory evidence]] about the chloroform searches and says they were about to give the jury a Notice of Supplemental Discovery but did not do so because jurors had reached a verdict.<ref>[http://www.cfnews13.com/static/articles/images/documents/CacheBack-errors-0719.pdf Central Florida News 13 Florida State Attorney's letter regarding CacheBack Errors], July 19, 2011.</ref><ref>Lizette Alvarez, [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/19/us/19casey.html?_r=1 Software Designer Reports Error in Anthony Trial], [[New York Times]], July 18, 2011.</ref>
July 26, 2011 – Judge Belvin Perry, Jr. rules juror names will remain secret until October 2011, citing public "outrage and distress" over the not guilty verdict. He also appeals to Florida legislators to bar the release of juror's names in some cases "in order to protect the safety and well-being of those citizens willing to serve."<ref>Ravelle Mohammed, [http://www.christianpost.com/news/casey-anthony-release-of-juror-names-postponed-52913/ Casey Anthony: Release of Juror Names Postponed], [[The Christian Post]], July 27, 2011.</ref>
August 1, 2011 – [[Orange County, Florida]] Circuit Judge Stan Strickland signs amended court documents that order Casey Anthony to return to Orlando within 72 hours to serve one year of supervised [[probation]] for the [[check fraud]] charge that Anthony pleaded guilty to in January 2010.<ref>[http://am.blogs.cnn.com/2011/08/02/casey-anthony-ordered-back-to-orlando-to-serve-one-year-of-probation/ Casey Anthony ordered back to Orlando to serve one year of probation], MSNBC, August 2, 2011.</ref> Jose Baez accuses Strickland of bias in the ruling.<ref>[http://www.myfoxtampabay.com/dpp/news/state/judge-accused-of-bias-in-anthony-case-08042011 Judge accused of bias in Anthony case], Fox News Channel, August 4, 2011.</ref> Strickland recuses himself from the case.<ref name=ABC-probation>Yunji De Nies and Jessica Hopper, [http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey_anthony_trial/casey-anthony-served-probation-jail-judge-belvin-perry/story?id=14239437 Casey Anthony Should Not Have Served Probation While in Jail: Judge], [[ABC News]], August 5, 2011.</ref>
August 5, 2011 – Baez obtains an emergency hearing with Judge Perry arguing Anthony already had served her probation and that Strickland no longer had jurisdiction over her. Perry postpones a decision calling the situation "a maze."<ref name=ABC-probation/>
August 10, 2011 – The [[Florida Department of Children and Families]] releases report concluding that Casey Anthony failed to protect Caylee, and that Casey's actions or lack of actions resulted in the death of the child. The finding has little legal relevance.<ref>Walter Pacheco, [http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/caylee-anthony/os-casey-anthony-dcf-report-20110811,0,1774056.story Casey Anthony's 'failure to protect' contributed to Caylee's death, DCF says], Orlando Sentinel, August 11, 2011.</ref>
August 12, 2011 – Judge Belvin Perry upholds Judge Strickland's order, ruling that Casey Anthony must return to Orlando to serve one year's probation for [[check fraud]], reporting no later than noon on August 26. The judge declares that her residential information during the probation period may be kept confidential because of threats made against her life.<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey-anthony-ordered-return-orlando-florida-serve-probation/story?id=14290966 "Casey Anthony Must Come Out of Hiding and Report for Probation"], [[ABC News]] August 12, 2011.</ref>
August 23, 2011 – After defense attorneys file motion to appeal Judge Perry's probation ruling,<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2011/CRIME/08/15/florida.casey.anthony/ Casey Anthony will appeal probation order, attorney says], [[CNN]], August 15, 2011.</ref> the Florida Fifth District Court of Appeals upholds it.<ref>Jessica Harper, [http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey_anthony_trial/casey-anthony-loses-probation-appeal-report-friday/story?id=14363579 Casey Anthony Loses Probation Appeal, Must Come Out of Hiding By Friday], [[ABC News]], August 23, 2011.</ref> Casey Anthony reports for probation at a secret location on August 24.<ref>[http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/aug/25/casey-anthony-reports-fla-probation-officials/ Casey Anthony reports to Fla. probation officials], [[Associated Press]], August 25, 2011.</ref>
September 15, 2011 – Judge Belvin Perry rules Casey Anthony must pay $97,000 of the $517,000 the state of Florida wanted her to pay for investigative and prosecution costs to the state under a provision of Florida sentencing law. He ruled she only had to pay those costs directly related to lying to law enforcement about the death of Caylee, i.e., search costs up to September 30, 2008, when the Sheriff's Office stopped investigating a missing-child case.<ref name=Winter>Michael Winter,[http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2011/09/casey-anthony-now-owes-217k-for-daughters-death-probe/1 Casey Anthony now owes $217K for Caylee's search], [[USA Today]], September 23, 2011.</ref><ref>Warren Richey, http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2011/0915/Casey-Anthony-ordered-to-reimburse-state-97-000.-How-that-still-could-rise Casey Anthony ordered to reimburse state $97,000. How that still could rise, [[Christian Science Monitor]], September 15, 2011.</ref> In earlier arguments Attorney [[Cheney Mason]] had called the prosecutors' attempts to exact the larger sum "sour grapes" because the prosecution lost its case. He told reporters that Anthony is indigent.<ref>Anthony Colarossi, [http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-09-02/news/os-casey-anthony-prosecution-costs-hearing-20110902_1_casey-anthony-cheney-mason-jose-baez Casey Anthony trial costs: How much she'll pay is up to judge], Orlando Sentinel, September 02, 2011.</ref>
September 23, 2011 – Judge Belvin Perry rules Casey Anthony must pay an additional $119,000 for the recalculated costs of the sheriff's search for Caylee Anthony, for a total of $217,000.<ref name=Winter/>
October 8, 2011 – Casey Anthony answers a few questions and takes the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]] repeatedly in a video deposition regarding the Zenaida Fernandez-Gonzales lawsuit.<ref>Christina Ng, [http://abcnews.go.com/US/casey-anthony-plead-video-deposition-undisclosed-location/story?id=14690394 Casey Anthony Pleads the Fifth in Video Deposition from Undisclosed Location], [[ABC News]], October 8, 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.clickorlando.com/news/29430207/detail.html Disguised Casey Anthony Takes The 5th] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011172754/http://www.clickorlando.com/news/29430207/detail.html |date=2011-10-11 }}. [[WKMG-TV]], 2011-10-08</ref>
October 25, 2011 – Judge Perry releases names of jurors in Casey Anthony trial.<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20125347-504083/casey-anthony-jurors-reportedly-in-hiding-after-judge-releases-their-names/ Casey Anthony jurors reportedly in hiding after judge releases their names], [[CBS News]], October 25, 2011.</ref>
== 2012 ==
February 15, 2012 – Casey's first monthly court payment of $20 is due.<ref>cfnews13timeline</ref>
June 11, 2012 – Casey motions for a new trial to have convictions of counts of lying to police overturned.
November 20, 2012 - [[WKMG-TV]] television in Orlando reported that police never investigated [[Firefox]] browser information on Casey Anthony's computer the day of Caylee's death; they only looked at [[Internet Explorer]] evidence. The station learned about this information from Casey Anthony's attorney Jose Baez who mentioned it in his book on the case.<ref>Tony Pipitone, [http://www.clickorlando.com/news/Cops-prosecutors-botched-Casey-Anthony-evidence/-/1637132/17495808/-/9rrlr7z/-/index.html Cops, prosecutors botched Casey Anthony evidence Computer search for 'foolproof suffocation' never found], [[WKMG-TV]], November 20, 2012.</ref>
==See also== * [http://www.browardbeat.com/casey-anthonys-atty-helps-in-race-for-judge/ Casey Anthony's Attorney is running for Broward County Judge in Florida] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wxg3PA2zOzg Attorney Johnathan Kasen defended Casey Anthony]
